headline: Rep. Watson Coleman Introduces Homes for Young Adults Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman, D-NJ, has introduced the Homes for Young Adults Act of 2025, aiming to address the urgent housing crisis facing young adults and youth across the nation. This legislation seeks to amend the United States Housing Act of 1937, to extend housing assistance specifically tailored for those aged 18 to 30 who experience unstable living conditions.

The introduction of this bill comes in response to alarming statistics revealing that approximately 4.2 million youth and young adults in the U.S. encounter homelessness each year. Disproportionately affecting communities of color and LGBTQ+ youth, the lack of accessible housing resources has forced many into congregate shelters, perpetuating cycles of poverty and instability. By removing systemic barriers that limit access to current housing assistance programs, the act aims to improve living conditions and overall outcomes for young individuals in need.

The Homes for Young Adults Act proposes the creation of an entitlement program that guarantees housing choice vouchers for eligible youth and young adults. This initiative highlights a critical need, as many young individuals can wait up to 140 days to secure stable housing through existing programs. Ensuring timely access to housing assistance will not only reduce homelessness but also contribute to enhanced educational and economic outcomes for this vulnerable demographic.

Additionally, the bill emphasizes comprehensive support services alongside housing assistance, enabling participants to navigate housing applications, access job training, and receive legal guidance. This holistic approach aims to empower young adults to achieve self-sufficiency while fostering healthier communities.

With bipartisan support anticipated, the Homes for Young Adults Act represents a significant step toward fostering equity in housing opportunities and supporting a critical population in overcoming the challenges of homelessness.

The bill (H.R. 2479) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Tlaib, Rashida [D-MI-12]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Aguilar Introduces No Hungry Kids in Schools Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Pete Aguilar, D-CA, has introduced the No Hungry Kids in Schools Act, aimed at improving access to nutritious meals for students across California. The bill seeks to amend the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to allow for statewide community eligibility for certain special assistance payments, ensuring that all eligible students receive free meals.

The necessity for this legislation emerges from escalating concerns over childhood hunger, exacerbated by the economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. Educational institutions continue to face challenges in providing adequate nutrition to students, with significant disparities in access to food across different regions. By implementing statewide eligibility, the proposed act intends to simplify administrative processes and reduce the stigma often associated with free meal programs.

The No Hungry Kids in Schools Act could significantly impact thousands of students by removing barriers to meal access, directly supporting their health and educational outcomes. Adopting a statewide approach means that all local educational agencies (LEAs) in California could collectively ensure that no student goes hungry. This initiative is also designed to encourage state funding to complement federal resources, thus further enhancing meal programs and their sustainability.

In addition, the legislation aligns with broader national goals to combat food insecurity among children, reflecting mounting bipartisan awareness of the critical importance of nutrition in education. The bill has garnered support from various stakeholders, including educators and health advocates who emphasize the link between proper nutrition and academic achievement.

Currently, the act is under consideration in the House Committee on Education and Workforce, where it is expected to receive close scrutiny as legislators deliberate on its potential benefits for families across the state.

headline: Rep. Allen Introduces TELL Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Rick Allen, R-GA, has introduced the TELL Act, designed to enhance transparency regarding data security for Americans using online platforms. This legislation aims to require any entity that maintains a website or distributes a mobile application, storing user information in China, to disclose where the data is stored and whether the Chinese Communist Party or state-owned entities have access to it.

The introduction of this bill comes amid growing concerns about the security of personal data in an era of increasing cyber threats and scrutiny about foreign influence. With the rise of data collection practices, especially from companies operating in countries with less stringent privacy regulations, Allen's proposal seeks to empower users to make informed decisions about their data. It aims to hold companies accountable for providing clear communication about data practices that might affect user privacy.

The potential impact of the TELL Act could be significant. By establishing mandatory disclosure protocols, it intends to create a higher standard for privacy practices and could influence how companies design their data collection strategies moving forward. Furthermore, if passed, the act would enable the Federal Trade Commission to enforce these requirements, classifying violations as unfair or deceptive practices under current law.

As it currently stands, the bill has been referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce for further consideration. The push for transparency surrounding data storage practices highlights a broader national dialogue regarding data privacy rights, especially as user concerns continue to escalate over the security of their personal information.

The bill (H.R. 2403) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Kaptur, Marcy [D-OH-9]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Miller-Meeks Introduces Bill to Continue Executive Order on English as Official Language
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meeks, R-IA, has introduced a new bill aimed at continuing the provisions of Executive Order 14224, which designates English as the official language of the United States. The proposed legislation seeks to ensure that this directive remains in effect indefinitely, reflecting an ongoing commitment to the use of English in government and public affairs.

The introduction of this bill comes amid growing discussions about national identity and language use within governmental contexts. Proponents believe that designating an official language can strengthen unity and facilitate communication among diverse populations. The bill's supporters argue that maintaining English as the official language is essential for effective governance and clarity in legal and administrative matters.

This legislation could significantly impact various sectors, including education, public service, and immigration. If enacted, it would mandate that all official government documents, public communications, and legislative proceedings be conducted in English. This move may streamline processes but could also generate debates regarding accessibility for non-English speakers.

Miller-Meeks, alongside fellow co-sponsor Rep. Harshbarger, emphasized the importance of understanding national values in the context of language use. The bill has been referred to the House Committees on Education and Workforce, as well as Oversight and Government Reform, for further examination and consideration.

As the bill progresses, it is likely to attract attention from various advocacy groups, both for and against the measure. Those in opposition may raise concerns about inclusivity and the implications for immigrants and diverse communities. With these discussions anticipated, the bill offers a focal point in the ongoing debate over the role of language in American society, governance, and identity.

The bill (H.R. 2453) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Harshbarger, Diana [R-TN-1]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Barr Introduces The White Oak Resilience Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Andy Barr, R-KY, has introduced The White Oak Resilience Act, aimed at restoring and enhancing the health of white oak forests across the United States. This legislation seeks to establish a coordinated approach among federal, state, and local organizations to promote the regeneration of white oak, an essential species for wildlife habitats and forest ecosystems.

The bill was introduced in response to the declining health of white oak populations, which has been attributed to factors such as climate change, pests, and habitat loss. By fostering a dedicated coalition focused on white oak restoration, the act emphasizes collaborative efforts involving various stakeholders, including government agencies and private organizations. This coalition will not only facilitate restoration initiatives but also address related policy challenges that hinder white oak regeneration.

Potential impacts of the bill extend beyond ecological benefits; revitalizing white oak forests could enhance recreational opportunities, improve biodiversity, and contribute to local economies reliant on forest resources. The act includes provisions for pilot projects in national forests and directs the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of the Interior to assess and enhance the restoration efforts further.

The initiative also proposes establishing a White Oak and Upland Oak Habitat Regeneration Program, which will provide grants and technical assistance for restoration activities. Additionally, it aims to address the shortage of tree seedlings in nurseries, ensuring adequate resources for restoration projects.

With bipartisan support, The White Oak Resilience Act is seen as a critical step toward preserving these vital ecosystems and enhancing resilience against environmental threats, ensuring their existence for future generations.

headline: Rep. Bonamici Introduces National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Sexual Harassment and Assault Prevention Improvements Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Suzanne Bonamici, D-OR, has introduced the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Sexual Harassment and Assault Prevention Improvements Act to strengthen measures against sexual harassment and assault within the agency. The bill aims to amend the National Defense Authorization Act of 2017 to enhance reporting procedures, improve victim anonymity, and increase accountability for incidents involving NOAA personnel.

The legislation was prompted by rising concerns over reports of sexual misconduct within NOAA, highlighting a need for significant reform. By establishing clearer policies and guidelines, the bill intends to not only protect employees but also foster a culture of safety and respect across the agency. It mandates more comprehensive annual reports on harassment cases, offering transparency on disciplinary actions taken against offenders.

This seasonal approach to policy reform aligns with growing awareness about workplace safety and accountability in federal agencies. Given the importance of NOAA’s mission in environmental monitoring and marine conservation, ensuring a supportive workplace for all employees is critical for the agency's operational effectiveness and reputation.

Incorporating provisions for restricted reporting will allow victims to disclose incidents without automatically triggering an investigation, aiming to empower survivors and encourage reporting. The bill also seeks to enhance oversight of investigations into harassment claims, thereby promoting a more responsive approach to such serious issues.

The introduction of this legislation demonstrates a commitment to improving workplace conditions within NOAA and reflects broader national conversations about workplace safety and gender equity. As this bill moves through the legislative process, it could have a lasting impact on safeguarding the rights and well-being of NOAA employees.

The bill (H.R. 2406) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 3 co-sponsors: Rep. Salazar, Maria Elvira [R-FL-27]...03/27/2025; Rep. Huffman, Jared [D-CA-2]...03/27/2025; Rep. Fitzpatrick, Brian K. [R-PA-1]...03/31/2025.

headline: Rep. Brecheen Introduces SNAP Reform and Upward Mobility Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Josh Brecheen, R-OK, has introduced the SNAP Reform and Upward Mobility Act of 2025, which aims to enhance the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) by incorporating measures designed to promote self-sufficiency among beneficiaries. This legislation, introduced on March 27, 2025, focuses on improving employment opportunities and reducing dependency on federal food assistance.

The bill comes in response to growing concerns about the effectiveness of current welfare programs, which some critics argue perpetuate poverty rather than alleviate it. By modifying eligibility requirements and increasing work mandates, Brecheen's proposal intends to encourage SNAP recipients to seek gainful employment. Key components include enhanced reporting on employment and training program outcomes and the introduction of state-matching funds to incentivize local investment in SNAP initiatives.

In addition to work requirements, this reform package aims to improve the measurement of poverty in the U.S. It seeks to provide a more comprehensive understanding of individuals receiving federal benefits by requesting detailed data from administering agencies. The anticipated outcome is a clearer picture of the correlation between SNAP participation and employment success, allowing policymakers to make informed decisions regarding benefits distribution.

The potential impact of this legislation could be significant, shifting the focus of SNAP from mere assistance to a pathway for upward mobility. By encouraging beneficiaries to gain employment, the act aims to reduce the overall financial burden on taxpayers while promoting economic independence among low-income households.

The bill has already been referred to the House Committees on Agriculture and Oversight and Government Reform for further deliberation, with hopes that it will bring substantive change to the current welfare framework. As discussions proceed, stakeholders will be closely monitoring the implications of Brecheen's proposed reforms.

The bill (H.R. 2407) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. Kennedy, Mike [R-UT-3]...03/27/2025; Rep. Grothman, Glenn [R-WI-6]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Carey Introduces Revitalizing Downtowns and Main Streets Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mike Carey, R-OH, has introduced the Revitalizing Downtowns and Main Streets Act, aiming to foster the conversion of non-residential buildings into affordable housing. This legislative initiative seeks to address the growing housing crisis by providing a tax credit incentive, thereby stimulating local economies and revitalizing urban areas.

The bill is a response to the pressing need for affordable housing options across the United States, where skyrocketing rents have disproportionately affected low- and middle-income families. By incentivizing the transformation of vacant or underused commercial properties into much-needed residential spaces, the measure aims to alleviate housing shortages and breathe new life into struggling downtown areas.

The proposed legislation outlines a 20% tax credit on qualified conversion expenditures for buildings that meet specific criteria, including being at least 20 years old and previously classified as non-residential. This credit is designed to encourage property owners and developers to engage in renovations, ultimately increasing the availability of affordable housing in urban centers.

As cities grapple with economic downturns and population shifts, the Revitalizing Downtowns and Main Streets Act also emphasizes the importance of developing housing near transportation and commercial hubs. By concentrating availability in these areas, the bill aims to reduce commuting times and improve residents' access to vital services and employment opportunities.

The bill has gained early support, with a growing list of co-sponsors reflecting bipartisan interest in addressing the housing crisis. If passed, it could significantly transform urban landscapes and provide a blueprint for enhancing community resilience against economic challenges. As such, Rep. Carey’s initiative not only targets housing but also aims to stimulate economic growth and support local businesses affected by changing market dynamics.

headline: Rep. Carson Introduces UNRWA Funding Emergency Restoration Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. André Carson, D-IN, has introduced the UNRWA Funding Emergency Restoration Act aimed at reinstating vital financial support for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA). This legislation seeks to address the urgent humanitarian needs of Palestinian refugees, particularly amidst escalating humanitarian crises in regions such as Gaza, Lebanon, and Syria.

The bill was introduced in response to recent cuts in funding to UNRWA, which has historically provided essential services, including education, healthcare, and emergency relief. Carson emphasized that diminishing support could exacerbate conditions for thousands of refugees reliant on UNRWA's services. The bill’s passage would not only restore funding but also reinforce the United States' commitment to humanitarian efforts in the region, promoting stability and supporting a peaceful resolution to ongoing conflicts.

With this legislation, the House aims to reaffirm its stance on the importance of UNRWA's role in mitigating the spread of disease and famine. The bill urges the Government of Israel to assist UNRWA in maintaining its neutrality and effectiveness, thereby fostering cooperation in humanitarian efforts. This bipartisan initiative reflects increased recognition of the complex challenges faced by Palestinian refugees and the implications for regional stability.

The UNRWA Funding Emergency Restoration Act proposes a multi-faceted approach, including a comprehensive review of UNRWA's operations to enhance efficiency and transparency. Reports on UNRWA’s implementation of recommendations from an independent review group will be mandated biannually. If successful, this legislation could significantly impact humanitarian aid and contribute to addressing the pressing needs of an underserved population.

headline: Rep. Case Introduces Indigenous Diplomacy and Engagement Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Ed Case, D-HI, introduced the Indigenous Diplomacy and Engagement Act on March 27, 2025, aimed at enhancing U.S. diplomatic relations with Indigenous peoples worldwide. The proposed legislation seeks to establish an Office for Indigenous Affairs to promote engagement and cooperation between the U.S. government and Indigenous communities, both domestically and internationally.

The Act emphasizes the need for a comprehensive strategy to foster relationships with Indigenous populations across various nations, given that there are approximately 476 million Indigenous individuals globally. It recognizes the significant challenges these communities face, including the preservation of their ancestral lands, cultures, and rights. By enhancing U.S. involvement with international Indigenous groups, the bill aims to support their goals and strengthen mutual interests.

This legislation comes in the wake of increasing global awareness of Indigenous rights, acknowledging prior international commitments made under the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. The bill outlines essential components for the new Office, including the appointment of a Coordinator for Indigenous Affairs, who will report directly to the Secretary of State and have ambassadorial rank.

The strategy mandated by the Act requires periodic assessment and development of specific goals regarding diplomacy with Indigenous communities. This includes identifying countries with significant Indigenous populations and evaluating the effectiveness of U.S. diplomatic efforts in those regions. By fostering multi-departmental collaboration, the Office's role is crucial in coordinating policies and resources aimed at enhancing these engagements.

As discussions surrounding global Indigenous rights continue to gain momentum, the Indigenous Diplomacy and Engagement Act represents a pivotal step towards a more inclusive U.S. foreign policy that respects and uplifts Indigenous voices on the global stage.

The bill (H.R. 2412) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. McGovern, James P. [D-MA-2]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Casten Introduces GREEN Appraisals Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Sean Casten, D-IL, has introduced the GREEN Appraisals Act, aimed at enhancing the valuation of residential properties through the integration of energy efficiency and renewable energy features in mortgage appraisals. This legislative initiative seeks to provide homeowners and prospective buyers the opportunity to include energy reports in their mortgage evaluations, potentially influencing appraisal values and financing options.

The bill was motivated by a growing recognition of the impact energy-efficient homes have on the environment and their long-term cost savings. As housing markets increasingly prioritize sustainability, providing accurate appraisals that reflect a home's energy characteristics is imperative. By mandating that energy reports be considered during appraisals, the bill intends to help homeowners demonstrate the financial benefits of energy-efficient improvements.

In addition to influencing appraisal processes, the GREEN Appraisals Act outlines clear guidelines for creditors on how to incorporate energy data into their underwriting practices. Starting March 1, 2026, creditors are to supply appraisers with energy reports, allowing for a thorough assessment of a property’s energy efficiency during the appraisal process. This is expected to not only elevate the appraised value of energy-efficient homes but also enhance access to affordable financing options for borrowers seeking energy-efficient properties.

The bill has been referred to both the House Financial Services Committee and the Veterans' Affairs Committee. Its potential impact is significant, aligning with national goals to improve energy sustainability in housing and foster a market that accurately reflects the value of energy efficiency. The broader aim is to encourage homeowners to invest in renewable energy features, ultimately contributing to a more energy-conscious housing market.

The bill (H.R. 2413) was introduced on 03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Castor Introduces Military and Civilian Partnership for Trauma Readiness Grant Program
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Kathy Castor, D-FL, has introduced a bill to amend the Public Health Service Act, aiming to reauthorize a vital military and civilian partnership aimed at improving trauma readiness. This initiative seeks to enhance collaboration between military and civilian healthcare providers, facilitating better responses to trauma situations.

The bill responds to growing concerns about trauma care readiness in both civilian and military settings, particularly highlighted during recent national emergencies and conflicts. By fostering this partnership, the program aims to ensure that both sectors are equipped to handle traumatic injuries more effectively, ultimately saving lives and improving patient outcomes.

If passed, the legislation will extend the grant program from fiscal years 2025 through 2029, allowing continued investment in training and resources. This program has historically provided critical funding to organizations that develop innovative strategies for trauma care, establishing a framework where military expertise can inform civilian practices and vice versa.

The impact of the bill could be significant, as it not only aims to enhance medical preparedness but also promotes the sharing of best practices between the military and civilian healthcare systems. This collaboration is essential for managing complex trauma cases, especially in mass casualty incidents or natural disasters.

Furthermore, the reauthorization comes at a time when many hospitals face challenges in maintaining sufficient trauma care capabilities due to workforce shortages and increasing patient loads. By enabling more effective training and resources, the partnership aims to fortify the trauma care infrastructure across the United States.

Castor, alongside co-sponsor Rep. Richard Hudson, emphasizes the necessity of this program in bridging critical gaps in trauma care and enhancing overall public health safety. The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce for further consideration.

The bill (H.R. 2414) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Hudson, Richard [R-NC-9]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Cohen Introduces Baseball Diplomacy Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Steve Cohen, D-TN, has introduced the Baseball Diplomacy Act, aiming to facilitate the participation of Cuban nationals in organized professional baseball within the United States. This legislation seeks to waive longstanding restrictions that have limited the ability of Cuban players to enter the U.S. for baseball opportunities.

The impetus behind this bill stems from the recognition of the rich tradition of baseball in Cuba and the vibrant talent of its players. Many Cuban athletes have demonstrated exceptional skill and have sought to play in Major League Baseball (MLB) teams. However, current embargo laws pose significant challenges, complicating their ability to travel and compete in the U.S. The Baseball Diplomacy Act aims to remove these barriers by allowing Cuban nationals to enter the U.S. on special visas for the duration of the baseball season, while also ensuring they can return to Cuba with their earned income.

This bill has the potential to significantly impact both MLB and the Cuban economy. By easing the process for Cuban athletes to join U.S. teams, it can enhance the level of play in professional baseball and create new avenues for cultural exchange. Additionally, this move is expected to build goodwill between the United States and Cuba, strengthening diplomatic relations through shared passions.

The Baseball Diplomacy Act represents a strategic shift in U.S. policy regarding Cuba, promoting sports as a means of fostering connections. As the bill moves through the legislative process, it will be reviewed by both the House Foreign Affairs and Judiciary Committees, where discussions around its implications will take place. If enacted, this legislation could pave the way for a new era in professional baseball and international cooperation.

The bill (H.R. 2415) was introduced on 03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Connolly Introduces Strengthening Agency Management and Oversight of Software Assets Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Gerald Connolly, D-VA, has introduced the Strengthening Agency Management and Oversight of Software Assets Act, aimed at enhancing the management and oversight of software assets across federal agencies. The bill emphasizes comprehensive assessments of software usage and entitlements, seeking to improve accountability and transparency in federal software asset management.

The act responds to ongoing concerns regarding inefficient software procurement and utilization within governmental operations. Many agencies struggle with duplicate software licenses and varying degrees of software interoperability, leading to unnecessary expenditures. By requiring a thorough assessment and inventory of software assets, the bill's intent is to streamline operations and minimize costs, ultimately enhancing federal efficiency.

The legislation mandates that each agency conduct a comprehensive assessment of its software inventory within 18 months of the act’s enactment. Key roles, such as the Chief Information Officer and Chief Financial Officer, will collaborate to analyze existing contracts and software entitlements. This requirement aims to shed light on unnecessary software expenditures and improve the transparency of high-cost software licenses.

In addition, the bill requires agencies to develop a plan for software modernization, consolidating licenses, and adopting cost-effective acquisition strategies. This proactive approach not only promises cost savings but also encourages agencies to utilize more enterprise licenses and open-source solutions, optimizing software use and interoperability.

Finally, the act establishes a government-wide framework for managing software assets, influencing long-term procurement strategies and compliance with software policies. By strengthening oversight, the act aims to enhance the overall transparency and accountability of federal software management practices.

The bill (H.R. 2417) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 3 co-sponsors: Rep. Fallon, Pat [R-TX-4]...03/27/2025; Rep. McClain Delaney, April [D-MD-6]...03/27/2025; Rep. Mace, Nancy [R-SC-1]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Davidson Introduces Federal Reserve Regulatory Oversight Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Warren Davidson, R-OH, has introduced the Federal Reserve Regulatory Oversight Act aimed at enhancing transparency and accountability within the Federal Reserve System. This legislation seeks to amend the Federal Reserve Act, specifically bringing the non-monetary policy-related functions of the Board of Governors under the appropriations process.

The Federal Reserve has been a central figure in the U.S. economic landscape, tasked with conducting monetary policy and overseeing financial institutions. However, concerns have arisen regarding the board’s regulatory operations that fall outside monetary policy. By incorporating these functions into the appropriations process, Davidson's bill aims to ensure that expenditures related to regulatory activities are subject to Congressional oversight. This includes costs associated with supervision, regulation, and operational tasks that support these regulatory duties.

The introduction of the bill is significant, as it comes amid ongoing debates about the Federal Reserve's independence and its broader role in the economy. Critics argue that increased oversight could lead to political interference, while proponents argue it is necessary for maintaining accountability in how taxpayer funds are utilized. The bill aims to establish clearer financial accountability by requiring that the Federal Reserve collects fees and assessments to cover its operational costs, thereby minimizing the reliance on general government funding.

Davidson’s proposal has been referred to the House Committee on Financial Services for further evaluation. If enacted, this act could reshape the dynamics of the Federal Reserve’s financial operations and strengthen the link between federal oversight and the financial regulatory framework. This potential shift in operations highlights a pivotal phase in U.S. economic policy, as stakeholders seek to balance independence with accountability.

The bill (H.R. 2418) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Donalds, Byron [R-FL-19]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Davidson Introduces Patient Fairness Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Warren Davidson, R-OH, introduced the Patient Fairness Act, a bill aimed at expanding access to health savings accounts (HSAs) for all individuals. The legislation was presented to address the growing need for more flexible healthcare financing options, particularly as healthcare costs continue to rise across the nation.

The Patient Fairness Act proposes significant reforms to existing HSA regulations, allowing all individuals to deduct contributions without the current eligibility restrictions tied to health plans. This change is designed to empower more Americans to save for healthcare expenses, ultimately increasing financial security for families. Additionally, the bill seeks to enhance contribution limits, allowing individuals to contribute up to $8,000 annually, which doubles for joint filers, plus an extra $3,000 for dependents. It also features provisions for individuals aged 55 and over to contribute additional funds, recognizing the unique healthcare needs of older Americans.

These legislative changes were introduced in response to concerns about inadequate access to affordable healthcare options, particularly during a time when many Americans are facing increased out-of-pocket expenses. By broadening the eligibility for HSAs and allowing higher contribution limits, the Patient Fairness Act aims to ensure that more citizens can better manage their health expenses.

Furthermore, the bill includes provisions aimed at improving price transparency in hospitals, working towards clearer communication regarding the costs of medical services. Rep. Davidson emphasized the importance of transparency, positing that clear pricing will facilitate informed consumer choices in healthcare services.

If passed, the Patient Fairness Act has the potential to reshape the way Americans save for healthcare, ultimately leading to a more equitable system better suited for today’s economic realities. The bill has been referred to both the House Ways and Means Committee and the Committee on Energy and Commerce for further consideration.

The bill (H.R. 2419) was introduced on 03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. DelBene Introduces Protecting Taxpayer Resources Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Suzan DelBene, D-WA, has introduced the Protecting Taxpayer Resources Act aimed at safeguarding the operational integrity of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). The bill mandates that any functions of the Department of Homeland Security imposed on IRS personnel must be preceded by an evaluation from the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration. 

The introduction of this bill comes amid concerns regarding the potential diversion of IRS resources to fulfill Homeland Security responsibilities. Lawmakers worry that such changes could impede the IRS's primary mission of ensuring taxpayer compliance and delivering quality service. The bill seeks to ensure that IRS personnel are adequately trained for any additional functions to maintain the agency’s reliability and public trust.

If passed, the Protecting Taxpayer Resources Act will require the Treasury Inspector General to issue a determination confirming that IRS staff can handle these responsibilities without compromising taxpayer services. Notably, this includes ensuring that the agency can effectively enforce tax laws while remaining committed to fairness and accuracy in its operations.

The potential impact of this legislation extends beyond bureaucratic regulations, as it addresses the ongoing tension between national security and taxpayer services. As resource allocation debates continue, this bill aims to prioritize the integrity of tax administration while preventing any potential overreach by the Department of Homeland Security.

DelBene’s initiative reflects a growing bipartisan concern regarding the appropriateness of assigning IRS staff to homeland security duties. By maintaining a clear distinction between these roles, the Protecting Taxpayer Resources Act seeks to uphold the foundational principles upon which the IRS was established, ensuring it can fully concentrate on its primary tasks of aiding taxpayers and enforcing tax laws. The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means for further consideration.

The bill (H.R. 2421) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Sewell, Terri A. [D-AL-7]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Donalds Introduces CAPE Canaveral Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Byron Donalds, R-FL, has introduced the CAPE Canaveral Act, aimed at relocating the headquarters of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) to Brevard County, Florida. This bill emphasizes efficiency and consolidation of aerospace programs within the space industry, potentially positioning Florida as a central hub for space exploration.

The introduction of the CAPE Canaveral Act follows increasing discussions on space program effectiveness and location optimization. Brevard County is home to the Kennedy Space Center and Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, established facilities that play a crucial role in both current rocket launches and future missions. By transferring NASA’s headquarters, the bill seeks to leverage existing infrastructure and workforce expertise to enhance operational efficiency and innovation in space technologies.

Proponents of the bill argue that relocating NASA's headquarters will foster closer collaboration with local businesses and educational institutions. This partnership could stimulate job growth, enhance local economies, and establish Florida as a leading state in the aerospace sector. Furthermore, these changes are anticipated to accelerate the development of cutting-edge technologies by integrating NASA's resources with the expertise of private sector enterprises and universities in the region.

This initiative also highlights the increasing competitiveness in the space industry, as other states vie to attract leading organizations. With the U.S. space program facing new challenges and heightened international competition, the CAPE Canaveral Act reflects a forward-thinking approach towards enhancing America’s strategic capability in space exploration.

As the bill progresses, it will be reviewed by the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology. The potential relocation is set to take place within a year of enactment, paving the way for a transformative shift in the nation's space operations.

headline: Rep. Estes Introduces Unfair Tax Prevention Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Ron Estes, R-KS, has introduced the Unfair Tax Prevention Act aimed at modifying the application of the base erosion and anti-abuse tax (BEAT) as it relates to foreign entities linked to jurisdictions that impose extraterritorial taxes. This bill, introduced on March 27, 2025, seeks to address concerns that the current tax regime unfairly impacts U.S. businesses with foreign ownership under specific circumstances.

The Unfair Tax Prevention Act arises in response to increasing reports that companies face tax liabilities from foreign jurisdictions that impose taxes based on profits linked to U.S. operations. By altering the BEAT's provisions, the legislation aims to relieve U.S. entities from potential double taxation that arises from these extraterritorial levies. Specifically, the bill delineates rules for determining the tax responsibilities of foreign-owned entities and aims to clarify when such taxes apply, specifically targeting those connected with foreign countries imposing extraterritorial taxes.

The potential impact of this bill hinges on alleviating the financial burden on U.S. companies engaged in international trade and operations, particularly those with foreign affiliates. Supporters argue that such reforms could enhance the competitiveness of U.S. businesses in the global market by eliminating the threat of dual taxation and creating a more favorable business environment.

As the bill moves to the House Committee on Ways and Means for review, its advocates anticipate that it will foster bipartisan support, given the increasing emphasis on protecting American economic interests in a complex global tax landscape. The introduction of this legislation marks a significant step toward addressing growing concerns related to international taxation and its repercussions on U.S. businesses operating abroad.

headline: Rep. Fallon Introduces Veterans Mental Health and Addiction Therapy Quality of Care Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Pat Fallon, R-TX, has introduced the Veterans Mental Health and Addiction Therapy Quality of Care Act, aimed at enhancing the quality of mental health and addiction treatment for veterans by comparing the services provided by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) with those from non-VA healthcare providers.

The motivation behind this legislation stems from ongoing concerns regarding the effectiveness and accessibility of mental health care for veterans. Reports of long wait times and varying quality in treatment options highlight the need for an in-depth analysis of current practices. This bill seeks to address such concerns by mandating an independent study that evaluates the quality of care veterans receive across various treatment modalities, including telehealth, outpatient services, and inpatient therapies.

If enacted, the bill would require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to partner with an external organization to conduct the study. The findings would be crucial for identifying gaps in service delivery and areas needing improvement. The independent assessment is expected to compare outcomes based on treatment duration and effectiveness while determining if practices align with established evidence-based medicine standards.

The potential impact of this legislation is significant, as improving mental health care is essential for addressing rising suicide rates among veterans. A comprehensive understanding of the differences in care quality could lead to more effective and integrated approaches tailored to veterans' unique needs. The study aims to be completed within 18 months, and its results will be shared with Congress and made publicly available to enhance transparency.

As it stands, the bill has been referred to the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs, where it awaits further discussion and possible amendments.

headline: Rep. Friedman Introduces Wildfire Homeowner Relief Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Laura Friedman, D-CA, has introduced the Wildfire Homeowner Relief Act, aiming to address the challenges faced by homeowners in areas prone to catastrophic wildfires. This bill mandates the Comptroller General of the United States to conduct a comprehensive study on a federal buyout program for homeowners willing to sell properties located in high-risk wildfire zones.

The increasing frequency and intensity of wildfires, fueled by climate change, have placed enormous stress on communities across California and other western states. Many residents in these high-risk areas have reported devastating losses as wildfires threaten their homes and livelihoods. The proposed bill seeks to mitigate these threats by investigating the feasibility of a federal buyout program that would allow homeowners to voluntarily sell their properties before and after a wildfire disaster occurs.

If enacted, this legislation could have significant implications for both individuals and communities. The study will evaluate existing federal grant programs and provide recommendations for a new program that focuses specifically on wildfire risk, glancing at successful buyout strategies from other disaster scenarios. Additionally, it will explore long-term land use plans aimed at reducing future wildfire risks and enhancing community safety.

In producing its report, due within a year of enactment, the Comptroller General will offer crucial insights into how local governments can best utilize buyouts, establish a national database for tracking these transactions, and ensure that financial resources effectively reach those in need. Given the ongoing challenges of climate change and disaster preparedness, the Wildfire Homeowner Relief Act reflects a proactive approach in supporting at-risk homeowners and fostering more resilient communities.

The bill (H.R. 2428) was introduced on [Introduction Date].

headline: Rep. Garbarino Introduces Comprehensive Campus Modernization Plan
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Andrew Garbarino, R-NY, has introduced a new bill aimed at directing the Secretary of Transportation to develop a comprehensive Campus Modernization Plan for the United States Merchant Marine Academy (USMMA). The legislation seeks to update the Academy’s aging infrastructure and facilities to provide current and future Midshipmen with the modern educational resources necessary for effective training.

In recent years, critics have highlighted that many of the facilities at the USMMA date back to its founding and have not undergone significant modernization. The proposed plan aims to ensure that these facilities meet today’s educational standards, addressing both academic training and physical readiness for future graduates. This update is essential, as graduates play a crucial role in the national defense and are notably integral to the U.S. Navy's Strategic Sealift Officer Program.

Furthermore, the bill points out that the modernization will not only enhance the educational experience but will also contribute to national security. Upgrading facilities to state-of-the-art standards is vital as the demand for qualified service-obligated licensed merchant mariners continues to grow. The bill is designed to create a more conducive learning environment, enabling Midshipmen to excel academically while preparing them for their commitments in both commercial maritime operations and national defense roles.

The Campus Modernization Plan will be informed by existing proposals and studies, such as the “Merchant Marine Academy Full Speed Ahead Plan.” Additionally, a significant budget allocation of $1.02 billion has been proposed over ten years to support infrastructure improvements. This investment reflects a commitment to maintaining the USMMA's status as a premier training institution for the maritime industry, ultimately ensuring it remains a vital component of U.S. maritime capabilities.

headline: Rep. Gill Introduces Legislation for Unique ZIP Code in Northlake
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Brandon Gill, R-TX, has introduced a bill aimed at establishing a single, unique ZIP Code for the town of Northlake, Texas. This legislation, if passed, would direct the United States Postal Service (USPS) to implement this change within 270 days of the bill's enactment.

The necessity for this bill stems from Northlake's growing population and the existing complications that arise from sharing ZIP Codes with neighboring areas. Currently, several neighborhoods within Northlake are utilizing the same ZIP Code as surrounding towns, which can lead to confusion in mail delivery, emergency services, and local identity. By designating a unique ZIP Code specifically for Northlake, proponents argue that it will streamline communication and enhance service efficiency for residents.

The potential impact of this bill could be significant. A dedicated ZIP Code would not only facilitate more accurate mail delivery but could also foster a greater sense of community pride and identity. Additionally, with Northlake experiencing rapid growth and development, the introduction of a unique postal code may enhance local business visibility and economic development efforts.

Historically, rural and suburban areas have struggled with the administrative hurdles of shared ZIP Codes. Many local officials have noted that designating unique postal identifiers helps facilitate better resource allocation and service delivery. As such, this bill aligns with a broader push towards improving infrastructure and public services in rapidly growing locales.

As the legislation moves forward, it has been referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform for further consideration. If successful, the bill will empower Northlake to establish its unique postal identity, ultimately benefiting its residents and businesses alike.

The bill (H.R. 2430) was introduced on 03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Graves Introduces Southwestern Power Administration Fund Establishment Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Sam Graves, R-MO, has introduced the Southwestern Power Administration Fund Establishment Act aimed at creating a dedicated fund to support the operations and management of the Southwestern Power Administration (SWPA). The fund, to be established in the U.S. Treasury, will facilitate power transmission, marketing, and maintenance operations crucial for the energy infrastructure in the region.

This bill is part of a broader effort to modernize and secure funding for the SWPA, which has faced financial constraints in recent years. By establishing this dedicated fund, the Administration aims to streamline budgeting processes and ensure that resources are allocated specifically for power transmission and related projects. The fund would consist of various receipts, including appropriated funds and transfer of unexpended balances from existing accounts, ensuring a steady flow of financial resources.

The impact of this legislation could be significant for the energy landscape in the Southwestern United States. By ensuring that the SWPA has more reliable funding, the bill aims to enhance the resilience of power infrastructure, potentially leading to improved reliability of electricity supply and support for renewable energy initiatives in the region. As power demands increase and infrastructure ages, this act could be a pivotal step in modernizing the energy framework essential to supporting local economies.

The SEC’s provisions emphasize transparency and accountability, requiring any excess funds in the newly established account to be returned to the Treasury as miscellaneous receipts. This legislation is now referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources and the Committee on Appropriations for further consideration, representing a promising step forward in energy administration reform.

headline: Rep. Green Introduces Reducing Medically Unnecessary Delays in Care Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mark E. Green, R-TN, has introduced the Reducing Medically Unnecessary Delays in Care Act of 2025 aimed at streamlining the prior authorization process for healthcare services under Medicare. The legislation seeks to ensure that medical necessity decisions are made exclusively by practicing physicians rather than administrative contractors, thereby reducing unnecessary delays in patient care.

The bill addresses growing concerns about the hurdles patients face in receiving timely medical treatments. Reports indicate that patients frequently experience prolonged waiting periods for approval of necessary medical procedures, leading to adverse health outcomes. By mandating that decisions regarding care are informed by clinical expertise, the new legislation aims to safeguard patient access to timely healthcare.

Under the proposed changes, Medicare administrative contractors and Medicare Advantage plans would be required to base coverage determinations solely on well-established clinical guidelines and standards, removing administrative barriers to care. This initiative is part of a broader effort to enhance healthcare efficiencies while prioritizing patient welfare, particularly in urgent medical situations.

Historically, the Medicare system has faced criticism for cumbersome prior authorization protocols that often hinder patient access to necessary services. The new act proposes to implement evidence-based practices that align medical decisions with actual healthcare needs rather than administrative interests, potentially improving overall patient satisfaction and outcomes.

Supporters of the bill believe that it could lead to a significant reduction in healthcare delays and foster a more responsive and patient-centered healthcare system. With an increasing number of stakeholders from both sides of the aisle expressing support, the legislation could pave the way for a critical transformation in how Medicare handles authorization decisions. The bill has been referred to the House Committees on Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce for further consideration.

headline: Rep. Wagner Introduces Financial Exploitation Prevention Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Ann Wagner, R-MO, has introduced the Financial Exploitation Prevention Act, aimed at enhancing protections for vulnerable adults against financial exploitation. The proposed legislation seeks to amend the Investment Company Act of 1940 by allowing registered open-end investment companies to postpone the redemption of securities if there is reasonable suspicion of financial exploitation involving specified adults.

The Financial Exploitation Prevention Act arises in response to the growing concern over the financial abuse of older adults and other vulnerable individuals, particularly in the context of investment activities. The bill addresses the alarming trend of financial exploitation, which often results in significant losses for those affected. By enabling investment firms to delay securities redemption, the bill aims to provide critical time for necessary investigations into potentially fraudulent activities.

Under the proposed legislation, investment companies would be required to document and retain certain customer information to assist in identifying signs of exploitation. If exploitation is suspected, these companies can postpone redeeming securities for up to 15 business days, with the potential for an additional 10-day extension if necessary, as long as the appropriate notices are given and a review is conducted.

The Financial Exploitation Prevention Act aims to safeguard adults aged 65 and older as well as any individual over 18 who may have impairments preventing them from protecting their financial interests. If passed, this bill represents a significant step toward proactive measures in the fight against financial exploitation, emphasizing the need for enhanced vigilance and a structured response from investment firms.

Wagner's initiative is backed by several bipartisan co-sponsors and is currently under consideration by the House Committee on Financial Services.

headline: Rep. Van Duyne Introduces Portable Ultrasound Reimbursement Equity Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Beth Van Duyne, R-TX, has introduced the Portable Ultrasound Reimbursement Equity Act aimed at enhancing Medicare coverage for portable ultrasound services. The bill seeks to amend the Social Security Act to ensure reimbursement for transportation and setup of portable ultrasound equipment, aligning it with current provisions for portable X-ray services.

This legislation comes in response to the growing need for accessible medical imaging, especially in rural and underserved areas where access to traditional imaging technologies may be limited. By facilitating reimbursement for portable ultrasounds, the bill aims to improve patient care and outcomes by making these services more readily available. 

According to the proposed bill, the U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services would be required to establish separate payment provisions for portable ultrasound services, similar to those already in place for portable X-ray services. The amendments would become effective for services rendered on or after January 1, 2027, thereby allowing time for the necessary adjustments and implementations within the Medicare system.

The Portable Ultrasound Reimbursement Equity Act seeks not only to streamline the payment process for medical providers but also to ensure that patients receive prompt diagnostics without the barriers of accessibility. In light of the emphasis on preventative health and early diagnosis, the bill is anticipated to have a significant impact on healthcare delivery, potentially reducing hospitalization rates by facilitating timely intervention.

With bipartisan support, the bill has been referred to the House Committees on Energy and Commerce, as well as Ways and Means, for further consideration. The proposed legislation highlights an ongoing commitment to improving healthcare accessibility and equity for all Americans.

headline: Rep. Tokuda Introduces Stop Illegal Campaign Coordination Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Jill Tokuda, D-HI, has introduced the Stop Illegal Campaign Coordination Act, aimed at amending the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to clarify the treatment of certain expenditures in political campaigns. The proposed legislation seeks to ensure that any expenditure materially consistent with instructions from candidates or political committees is considered coordinated, which would impose stricter regulations on campaign financing.

The bill is a direct response to growing concerns over the intertwining of outside spending and candidate campaigns, especially following the Supreme Court's Citizens United ruling, which allowed for unrestricted independent expenditures. By establishing definitive criteria for what constitutes coordinated spending, the act aims to mitigate the influence of dark money in politics and promote transparency.

The potential impact of the Stop Illegal Campaign Coordination Act is significant; it could limit the effectiveness of independent expenditures that operate in tandem with candidates' campaigns without formally coordinating. Under the proposed changes, if a committee or candidate provides guidance on how funds should be spent or shared relevant information about target demographics, these expenditures would fall under stricter regulations, thereby enhancing accountability.

The emergence of this bill reflects a growing acknowledgment among lawmakers of the need for comprehensive campaign finance reform. While proponents argue it will strengthen the democratic process by reducing outside influence, critics suggest it poses challenges for independent groups advocating for various political causes. As the legislation moves through the House Administration Committee, it will likely ignite debate over the balance between free speech and the integrity of electoral processes.

The bill (H.R. 2476) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 4 co-sponsors: Rep. Tonko, Paul [D-NY-20]...03/27/2025; Rep. Case, Ed [D-HI-1]...03/27/2025; Rep. Jayapal, Pramila [D-WA-7]...03/27/2025; Rep. Balint, Becca [D-VT-At Large]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Tlaib Introduces Youth Homelessness Guaranteed Income Pilot Program Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-MI, has introduced the Youth Homelessness Guaranteed Income Pilot Program Act aimed at addressing the pressing issue of youth homelessness across the United States. This legislation seeks to provide targeted financial assistance and supportive services to economically disadvantaged young individuals facing homelessness.

The bill was introduced in response to alarming statistics indicating that an estimated 4.2 million youth and young adults experience homelessness each year in the U.S. Many of these individuals face systemic barriers, including economic disparities and discrimination, which hinder their access to safe and stable housing. Through the proposed pilot program, the act intends to offer both financial support and resources designed to empower participants with crucial skills and educational opportunities.

Under the program, selected participants will receive cash payments for 36 consecutive months, which will be determined based on fair market rent rates in their respective areas. In addition to financial assistance, the program will provide services such as housing navigation, financial coaching, and workforce development to help participants secure long-term housing solutions and economic stability.

The implementation of this pilot initiative is expected to yield important data on the effectiveness of guaranteed income as a strategy for combating youth homelessness. A comprehensive study will follow the program, aiming to assess its impact on housing stability, health outcomes, and overall welfare of participants.

With the introduction of this legislation, Rep. Tlaib and her co-sponsors underscore the importance of addressing youth homelessness through innovative economic support methods, aiming to create a more equitable future for vulnerable young populations.

headline: Rep. Taylor Introduces Expanding Appalachia’s Broadband Access Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. David Taylor, R-OH, has introduced the Expanding Appalachia’s Broadband Access Act aimed at enhancing broadband access in under-served regions of the Appalachian area. The bill seeks to empower the Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC) to integrate low-orbit satellite technology into its broadband initiatives, fostering improved connectivity for businesses and residents alike.

The introduction of this bill responds to the persistent digital divide that has afflicted rural Appalachia, where many communities lack reliable internet access. By leveraging low-orbit satellites, the legislation aims to explore innovative solutions to bridge this gap, particularly in economically disadvantaged areas. The key component of the measure is a mandated study by the Comptroller General to assess the feasibility of incorporating satellite technology, focusing on its potential to drive economic growth and its cost-effectiveness.

Should the bill pass, it could significantly impact the region's economic landscape. Enhanced internet access is anticipated to empower local businesses, attract new investments, and enable remote work opportunities. Insights from the study would also shed light on existing satellite technologies, evaluating not just their operational capabilities but their implications for long-term economic development.

The broader context of this legislative move highlights the ongoing national effort to modernize infrastructure and improve telecommunications in rural areas, an initiative that has gained momentum in recent years. This effort is particularly crucial in light of the COVID-19 pandemic, which underscored the critical need for reliable internet connectivity for education, healthcare, and remote work.

As the bill moves to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, it represents a key step towards addressing the urgent connectivity needs of Appalachia, with an eye towards fostering sustainable economic growth and resilience in the region.

The bill (H.R. 2474) was introduced on 03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Sykes Introduces Healthy Food Access for All Americans Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Emilia Strong Sykes, D-OH, has introduced the Healthy Food Access for All Americans Act aimed at enhancing access to nutritious food options in underserved areas, also known as food deserts. The proposed legislation establishes new tax credits and grant programs to incentivize grocery stores and food banks to operate in these communities.

The bill addresses a critical deficiency in many low-income areas, where access to fresh produce and healthy food options is severely limited. By offering financial incentives, the Healthy Food Access for All Americans Act seeks to increase the number of grocery stores and healthier food outlets in regions that currently lack these resources. Statistics show that a significant portion of low-income populations reside in areas where they cannot afford or access quality food, leading to higher rates of diet-related illnesses.

Under the act, certified special access food providers can receive tax credits of up to 15% for building new grocery stores or renovating existing ones. Additionally, a grant program will provide funds to food banks and temporary access merchants like farmers markets, thereby ensuring a wider distribution of nutritious food in food deserts.

The legislation also mandates annual updates to the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Access Research Atlas, ensuring that policymakers have timely data on food retailers and can better target areas in need. Rep. Sykes emphasizes the importance of addressing food insecurity and improving health outcomes through better access to healthy foods, asserting that this bill will create lasting change in vulnerable communities.

The Healthy Food Access for All Americans Act has been referred to the House Committees on Ways and Means and Agriculture for further consideration.

The bill (H.R. 2473) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. McClellan, Jennifer L. [D-VA-4]...03/27/2025; Del. Norton, Eleanor Holmes [D-DC-At Large]...04/07/2025.

headline: Rep. Sykes Introduces INFANTS Act of 2025
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Emilia Strong Sykes, D-OH, has introduced the INFANTS Act of 2025, a pivotal piece of legislation aimed at enhancing the safety of infant and toddler food products in the United States. The bill seeks to amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act by establishing rigorous sampling and testing requirements for contaminants across all infant and toddler food items.

The introduction of this bill comes in response to growing concerns over food safety, particularly in the infant demographic, where products are susceptible to toxic elements such as lead and arsenic. Recent reports of contaminated baby food have heightened public scrutiny and pressured Congress to act decisively to protect vulnerable children.

The INFANTS Act outlines specific requirements for food manufacturers, mandating them to collect representative samples of their products and conduct thorough testing for harmful contaminants. This includes a structured testing frequency, with the expectation that sampling occurs at least once every quarter. To enforce compliance, the bill stipulates the maintenance of detailed records for all testing conducted, which must be made available for inspection by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

The bill also emphasizes mandating a recall if any product is found to be adulterated with dangerous contaminants, ensuring that manufacturers take immediate corrective actions to protect public health. By reinforcing laboratory accreditation standards and establishing monitoring practices for critical pathogens like Salmonella, the legislation aims to bolster consumer confidence in food safety.

With strong bipartisan support anticipated, the INFANTS Act of 2025 represents an essential step toward ensuring that the nutritional needs of infants and toddlers are met while safeguarding their health against preventable contaminants.

The bill (H.R. 2472) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 3 co-sponsors: Rep. Pallone, Frank [D-NJ-6]...03/27/2025; Rep. Krishnamoorthi, Raja [D-IL-8]...03/27/2025; Del. Norton, Eleanor Holmes [D-DC-At Large]...04/07/2025.

headline: Rep. Swalwell Introduces Right Drug Dose Now Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-CA, has introduced the Right Drug Dose Now Act of 2025, aiming to enhance patient safety by updating the National Action Plan for Adverse Drug Event Prevention. The bill seeks to integrate advancements in pharmacogenomic research into healthcare systems to minimize adverse drug reactions through better-informed prescriptions.

Swalwell's legislation is designed to address persistent issues with adverse drug events, which have been a significant concern for healthcare practitioners and patients alike. By leveraging the latest advancements in pharmacogenomics, the act aims to ensure that medication prescriptions bolster patient outcomes based on individual genetic profiles. This is a crucial development in avoiding harmful drug interactions that compromise patient health.

The bill mandates actions within 180 days of enactment, calling upon the Secretary of Health and Human Services to convene relevant federal stakeholders to revise the National Action Plan. This revision aims to include contemporary scientific understanding of drug-gene interactions and will assess the effectiveness of pharmacogenetic testing as a preventative measure against adverse reactions.

One of the critical components of the legislation is the enhancement of electronic health records (EHRs). The act promotes improvements that support the integration of pharmacogenomic information into healthcare systems. Specifically, this includes alerts during computerized provider order entry to determine appropriate pharmacogenomic testing and identify drug-gene interactions. As a result, healthcare providers will be better equipped to personalize patient medication plans effectively.

The Right Drug Dose Now Act not only aims to inform healthcare professionals about pharmacogenomic testing but also encourages the development of user-friendly reporting systems for adverse drug events. This concept aligns with ongoing efforts to enhance patient safety and established best practices in personalized medicine. By integrating more comprehensive genetic data into clinical decision-making, the legislation envisions significant strides toward reducing avoidable medication-related harm.

The bill (H.R. 2471) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Crenshaw, Dan [R-TX-2]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Subramanyam Introduces COST of Relocations Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Suhas Subramanyam, D-VA, has introduced the COST of Relocations Act, a new legislative initiative aimed at enhancing transparency and accountability in federal agency relocations. The bill mandates that federal agencies conduct comprehensive benefit-cost analyses before moving employment positions, ensuring that decision-makers assess the potential impacts on both employees and the agency's mission.

The introduction of the COST of Relocations Act comes in response to growing concerns regarding the efficiency of federal relocations and their effects on employee morale and public service delivery. By requiring detailed analyses, the legislation seeks to prevent poorly planned moves that may disrupt agency operations and lead to unnecessary costs. Advocates of the bill argue that thorough evaluations can provide valuable insights into the long-term implications of relocating federal jobs, thereby promoting fiscal responsibility and improved service outcomes.

Under the proposed bill, federal agencies would need to submit unredacted reports of their benefit-cost analyses to their respective Offices of Inspector General. These reports will detail the anticipated outcomes of relocations, including how they align with the agency's objectives and the necessary resources for successful implementation. The Office of Inspector General will play a crucial role in reviewing these analyses and reporting their findings to Congress.

This legislation reflects ongoing efforts to ensure that federal government practices align with accountability standards and best practices in management. If enacted, the COST of Relocations Act would mark a significant shift in how federal relocations are approached, emphasizing the importance of strategic planning and stakeholder engagement while safeguarding taxpayer interests.

headline: Rep. Strickland Introduces Abortion DOULAS Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Marilyn Strickland, D-WA, has introduced the Abortion DOULAS Act aiming to evaluate the benefits and accessibility of abortion doula care. The legislation mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to conduct a comprehensive study on the impact of abortion doulas, who provide emotional, informational, and logistical support to individuals seeking abortions.

The rise of this bill comes in the wake of growing concerns about access to reproductive healthcare post-Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization. This pivotal Supreme Court decision significantly affected abortion rights, leading to heightened barriers, especially for marginalized communities. Strickland's initiative recognizes the importance of doulas in navigating these challenges, especially for those facing systemic barriers to care.

The proposed study will assess how abortion doula care influences patient experience and outcomes, focusing on the support provided before, during, and after abortion procedures. By highlighting the role of doulas in various settings—including hospitals, clinics, and home visits—this legislation seeks to validate and potentially integrate this support into broader healthcare frameworks.

Furthermore, the bill addresses existing barriers to accessing doula care, such as limited awareness and financial constraints, particularly among communities of color and low-income individuals. The legislation aims not only to gather data but also to provide actionable recommendations to improve Medicaid and insurance coverage for doula services, ensuring that essential support is accessible to all individuals.

The Abortion DOULAS Act represents a significant step towards enhancing comprehensive reproductive healthcare, and it emphasizes the necessity of cultural competence and patient advocacy in supporting those undergoing abortions. Strickland's proposal is poised to redefine the landscape of reproductive care by advocating for the integration of doula support into healthcare policies.

The bill (H.R. 2469) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. Moore, Gwen [D-WI-4]...03/27/2025; Rep. Brownley, Julia [D-CA-26]...03/31/2025.

headline: Rep. Steil Introduces No Sanctions Relief for Terrorists Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Bryan Steil, R-WI, has introduced the No Sanctions Relief for Terrorists Act, aimed at tightening restrictions on Iran by prohibiting any waivers or licenses that would relieve sanctions imposed against individuals and entities involved in terrorism.

The legislative move comes amid increasing concerns over Iran's continued support for various terrorist organizations and activities that undermine regional stability. By enforcing stricter sanctions, the bill seeks to hold Iranian entities accountable under U.S. law, significantly impacting ongoing diplomatic negotiations with Tehran. It reflects a broader strategy to deter U.S. adversaries by signaling a commitment to maintaining robust sanctions as a foreign policy tool.

If passed, the act will prevent the issuance of licenses for transactions with Iranian individuals or entities already designated for sanctions, unless the President certifies that they are no longer involved in terrorism. This proposal effectively reinforces existing measures against terrorism financing—a critical component of U.S. national security policy, especially in light of rising tensions in the Middle East.

Moreover, the introduction of this bill reflects a growing bipartisan consensus on the need for a firm stance against terrorism financing. Legislative sponsors hope that implementing the act will deter Iranian entities from engaging in illicit activities that threaten not only regional but also global security.

This act aligns with ongoing efforts from lawmakers to streamline sanctions policy and ensure that U.S. foreign aid and diplomacy do not inadvertently benefit entities that engage in terrorism or its support. By holding firm to sanction protocols, the U.S. aims to reinforce its stance globally and emphasize its commitment to combating terror financing. The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs for further consideration.

The bill (H.R. 2468) introduced on 03/27/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. Moore, Barry [R-AL-1]...03/27/2025; Rep. Schmidt, Derek [R-KS-2]...03/31/2025.

headline: Rep. Stansbury Introduces America’s Red Rock Wilderness Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Melanie Stansbury, D-NM, has introduced the America’s Red Rock Wilderness Act, aiming to designate significant portions of Utah's red rock canyons and desert areas as protected wilderness. The proposed legislation seeks to safeguard the ecological and cultural richness of these regions for future generations while acknowledging the land's historical importance to Indigenous communities.

The bill comes in response to ongoing debates about land conservation and climate change mitigation. By designating these areas as wilderness, the act intends to enhance biodiversity and protect critical habitats from climate change impacts, as well as to promote outdoor recreational activities such as hiking and camping. The proposal is poised to affect an extensive expanse of land across the Colorado Plateau and the Great Basin Deserts, encompassing areas like the Grand Staircase-Escalante and the Moab-La Sal Canyons.

Stansbury's initiative is part of a broader movement to address environmental conservation through legislative action. The legislation, supported by bipartisan stakeholders, emphasizes the need for policies that ensure landscape preservation and the reduction of carbon emissions stemming from land development and fossil fuel extraction. 

By facilitating the legal protection of these uniquely beautiful landscapes, the America’s Red Rock Wilderness Act would contribute to the goal of protecting at least 30% of the nation’s lands and waters by 2030, a commitment echoed in various international conservation agreements. Additionally, it aims to forge a balance between development and conservation while recognizing the enduring ties between the land and Indigenous cultures.

As this bill advances through the legislative process, it stands as a testament to growing public demand for robust environmental protection measures and the rethinking of America's approach to land use history.

headline: Rep. Sorensen Introduces Jay P. Larson Post Office Building Bill
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Eric Sorensen, D-IL, has introduced a bill aiming to designate the United States Postal Service facility at 5225 Harrison Avenue in Rockford, Illinois, as the Jay P. Larson Post Office Building. This proposal honors the legacy of esteemed local figure Jay P. Larson, who significantly contributed to the community and public service.

The bill seeks to commemorate Larson's dedication and service to Rockford, recognizing the impact he had during his lifetime. By naming the post office after him, the community aims to keep his memory alive and inspire future generations to emulate his commitment to civic duties and public engagement. The legislation was introduced on March 27, 2025, and has been referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform for further consideration.

Name designations for public facilities are significant as they reflect local pride and history. Larson, a beloved member of the Rockford community, served in various capacities that improved the lives of residents, making this recognition particularly poignant for many locals. The post office serves as a convenient hub for residents and visitors; thus, the new name will resonate with community members visiting the facility.

This initiative is part of a broader effort by Rep. Sorensen to strengthen community ties and highlight local heroes through meaningful tributes. Should the bill pass, it will also inspire other communities to recognize their influential figures, fostering a spirit of remembrance and gratitude.

As the legislative process unfolds, supporters hope the bill will garner swift approval, allowing the community to celebrate one of its own in a permanent and impactful way.
