headline: Rep. Carey Introduces Improve Transparency and Stability for Families and Children Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mike Carey, R-OH, has introduced the Improve Transparency and Stability for Families and Children Act aimed at enhancing fund distribution and management within the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program. This bill seeks to establish clearer deadlines for when states should obligate and spend TANF funds, enhancing fiscal responsibility in social welfare programs.

The proposed legislation comes in response to rising concerns about the effective use of federal aid to states under the TANF block grant structure. Currently, states have flexibility in how they manage these funds, which can lead to delays or misallocation. By instituting firm deadlines, the bill encourages timely investment in programs that support needy families, ensuring that assistance reaches those in need when it is most crucial.

In addition to setting deadlines for fund allocation, the bill allows states to create rainy day funds, enabling them to reserve a portion of their TANF funds for urgent future needs. This feature aims to promote financial stability while giving states the freedom to navigate economic fluctuations without jeopardizing essential support services.

Supporters of the bill argue that these measures will significantly enhance transparency in how states use federal assistance. By knowing when funds must be obligated and spent, both policymakers and the public can better track the effectiveness of TANF programs in reducing poverty and supporting family stability.

The Improve Transparency and Stability for Families and Children Act was introduced on March 26, 2025, and has been referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means for further discussion and potential amendments. If passed, it could greatly impact social welfare strategies and bolster support for American families struggling in uncertain economic conditions.

The bill (H.R. 2359) introduced on 03/26/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Miller, Max L. [R-OH-7]...03/26/2025.

headline: Rep. Carter Introduces Permanent Exemption for School Bus Driver Inspections
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. John R. Carter, R-TX, has introduced a bill aimed at permanently extending the exemption from the engine compartment portion of the pre-trip vehicle inspection skills testing requirement for school bus drivers. This legislation seeks to alleviate some of the rigorous testing barriers currently faced by aspiring school bus drivers, simplifying the process to encourage more individuals to enter this critical field.

The initiative comes as many states continue to grapple with a shortage of school bus drivers. By removing the requirement for inspecting the engine compartment, the bill aims to expedite training and licensing for new drivers, thereby addressing staffing shortages that have affected school operations nationwide. The modified requirement is expected to streamline the path to licensure, ultimately facilitating a more efficient recruitment process.

Currently, under federal regulations, school bus drivers must complete a skills test that includes an engine compartment inspection. This component has been identified as a challenging hurdle for many candidates, contributing to potential delays in licensing and onboarding. The proposed bill, which aligns with a temporary exemption previously granted, aims to make this exemption permanent for a six-year period, during which participating states will report on the number of drivers obtaining a commercial driver's license under this change.

Carter’s legislative effort reflects a broader commitment to enhancing the school transportation system's sustainability and reliability. Schools play a vital role in supporting students' educational journeys, and ensuring adequate transportation resources is fundamental for community engagement. The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure for further evaluation and discussion.

headline: Rep. Connolly Introduces Cameras in the Courtroom Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Gerald Connolly, D-VA, has introduced the Cameras in the Courtroom Act, a significant legislative move aimed at permitting televised coverage of Supreme Court proceedings. This bill was presented to promote transparency and public engagement with the judicial process, reflecting growing calls for greater accessibility in government operations.

This push for cameras in the courtroom comes at a time when public interest in legal proceedings is booming, especially following high-profile Supreme Court cases that have garnered national attention. Supporters argue that live broadcasts of Supreme Court hearings would enhance the public's understanding of judicial deliberations and the workings of the nation's highest court. By allowing cameras, the legislation seeks to demystify judicial proceedings and foster a more informed citizenry.

The proposed bill allows for televised coverage of all open sessions, with exceptions made only if a majority of justices deem it constitutes a violation of due process for involved parties. This provision aims to balance the need for transparency with the protection of individual rights within the judicial system. If passed, it would amend Title 28 of the United States Code, fundamentally altering how the Supreme Court engages with the public.

By advocating for this bill, Rep. Connolly positions himself as a champion of accountability in the judicial system, mirroring movements in various states that have seen implementations of cameras in smaller courts. The Cameras in the Courtroom Act reflects a broader trend towards transparency in government and an effort to modernize judiciary practices that have remained unchanged for decades. The Judiciary Committee will now review the bill as it progresses through the legislative process.

headline: Rep. De La Cruz Introduces VA Home Loan Awareness Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Monica De La Cruz, R-TX, has introduced the VA Home Loan Awareness Act, a legislative measure aimed at increasing awareness of the home loan programs provided by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). This bill seeks to require enterprises to include a specific disclaimer on the Uniform Residential Loan Application, highlighting potential VA loan eligibility for veterans and service members.

The VA Home Loan Awareness Act aims to address the common issue of underutilization of VA loan benefits among eligible individuals. Many veterans remain unaware of their eligibility for these government-backed loans, which can provide substantial financial advantages, including no down payment and competitive interest rates. By mandating a disclaimer on the key application form, the legislation seeks to inform more service members and veterans about the opportunities available to them.

In addition to increasing awareness, the bill instructs the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to conduct a study within 18 months of enactment. This study will evaluate the effectiveness of the disclosure and ensure that at least 80% of lenders using the Uniform Residential Loan Application incorporate the new disclaimer into their processes. This oversight aims to maximize the outreach of the program and improve access to benefits for those who have served in the military.

The introduction of this bill comes at a time when national conversations around veterans' benefits are increasingly pertinent, as many veterans face financial hardships. With rising housing costs, this bill represents a proactive approach to ensure veterans can leverage valuable financial resources that they earned through their service. The bill has garnered support from a bipartisan group of representatives, indicating broad recognition of the need for increased awareness around VA home loan programs.

headline: Rep. DeGette Introduces DOGE POUND Act of 2025
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Diana DeGette, D-CO, has introduced the DOGE POUND Act of 2025, aiming to tighten access controls to systems that contain individually identifiable health information. This legislation is designed to prevent unauthorized individuals from accessing sensitive health data managed by the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

The bill comes in response to increasing concerns over data breaches and the implications they can have on privacy and security. Recent high-profile incidents have raised alarms regarding the potential for misuse of personal health information, prompting lawmakers to ensure stricter regulations surrounding access. The DOGE POUND Act seeks to establish clear criteria outlining who can access HHS health information systems, emphasizing the importance of protecting citizens’ privacy.

Under this proposed law, only those who are HHS employees or contractors with appropriate security clearances and completed training in privacy laws would be allowed access to these systems. The legislation also stipulates penalties for unauthorized access, which could include imprisonment of up to five years. The act further mandates that the Inspector General of HHS conduct investigations and report each instance of unauthorized access, ensuring transparency and accountability.

This bill emphasizes the critical need for safeguarding personal health information in an increasingly digital age, where security measures must evolve to counteract sophisticated cyber threats. Proponents argue that strengthening access controls will not only enhance individual privacy but also restore public trust in the management of health data. As the bill progresses through the legislative process, it aims to address these pressing concerns while upholding the integrity of the health information systems that millions rely on daily.

headline: Rep. Edwards Introduces Helene Small Business Recovery Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Chuck Edwards, R-NC, has introduced the Helene Small Business Recovery Act, aimed at providing crucial support for small businesses impacted by recent natural disasters. The bill seeks to waive the duplication of benefits for certain disaster assistance under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act, thereby streamlining financial aid for businesses struggling to recover from major disasters.

The Helene Small Business Recovery Act was developed in response to the increasing frequency and severity of natural disasters, which have left many small businesses facing financial devastation. Under current law, businesses often struggle to navigate complex regulations that restrict the receipt of multiple forms of assistance for the same disaster, hindering their recovery efforts. This bill aims to simplify this process by allowing the President to waive those restrictions when requested by state governors, facilitating faster access to vital resources.

If enacted, the legislation is expected to bolster economic resilience in communities affected by disasters. By allowing businesses to receive necessary support without the burden of complex eligibility requirements, the bill could help promote quicker recovery and job retention in hard-hit areas. It addresses concerns that bureaucratic obstacles have delayed assistance during critical recovery periods.

The bill specifically targets assistance related to disasters declared under the Stafford Act in 2023 and 2024, highlighting the immediate needs faced by small businesses in the aftermath of these events. With bipartisan backing from other North Carolina representatives, the Helene Small Business Recovery Act aims to provide a more effective safety net for the state’s entrepreneurs and small enterprises. As the bill moves through the legislative process, it seeks to emphasize the need for responsive and responsible disaster recovery efforts across the nation.

The bill (H.R. 2364) introduced on 03/26/2025 has 3 co-sponsors: Rep. Davis, Donald G. [D-NC-1]...03/26/2025; Rep. Foxx, Virginia [R-NC-5]...03/26/2025; Rep. Rouzer, David [R-NC-7]...03/27/2025.

headline: Rep. Emmer Introduces Securities Clarity Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Tom Emmer, R-MN, has introduced the Securities Clarity Act, aiming to clarify the definition of securities under U.S. law by excluding investment contract assets from this classification. This legislative move is designed to enhance regulatory transparency and facilitate investment in digital assets.

The Securities Clarity Act of 2025 seeks to amend the Securities Act of 1933 and other related laws, specifying that an investment contract asset is a fungible digital representation of value that can be transferred directly between parties without intermediaries. By offering this definition, the bill aims to ease the uncertainty surrounding the regulation of digital assets, which has become a key issue as cryptocurrencies and related investments continue to grow in popularity.

The introduction of this bill comes in response to calls from industry stakeholders who argue that existing regulations stifle innovation in the digital finance sector. By distinguishing investment contract assets from traditional securities, the Act could foster a more inviting environment for investors and entrepreneurs in the burgeoning cryptocurrency market.

Supporters of the legislation contend that it would help clarify the legal status of digital assets, potentially reducing regulatory burdens on companies that seek to create investment products based on blockchain technology. This clarity is seen as crucial for encouraging responsible investment in digital assets while still maintaining consumer protections.

Currently, the bill has been referred to the House Committee on Financial Services for further consideration. If passed, it could significantly change the landscape for digital asset regulation, aligning U.S. policies more closely with innovations emerging in the financial technology space. As discussions proceed, the potential impact on investors, businesses, and the landscape of digital assets remains a focal point of interest.

The bill (H.R. 2365) introduced on 03/26/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Soto, Darren [D-FL-9]...03/26/2025.

headline: Rep. Escobar Introduces American Families United Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Veronica Escobar, D-TX, has introduced the American Families United Act aimed at reforming immigration policies to enhance family unity within the United States. The bill proposes amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act, allowing greater discretion for immigration officials to prevent the removal of certain undocumented immigrants who are immediate family members of U.S. citizens.

This legislation was introduced in light of ongoing concerns about the impact of immigration enforcement on family structures, particularly among mixed-status families where some members are U.S. citizens and others are not. The goal is to ensure that the immigration system prioritizes family unity, recognizing that separation can lead to significant emotional and financial hardship. Research indicates that family separation exacerbates mental health issues and disrupts the social fabric of communities, prompting calls for legislative action.

One significant aspect of the American Families United Act is the provision granting the Attorney General and the Secretary of Homeland Security the discretion to decline removal proceedings when it poses undue hardship on U.S. citizen family members. This includes the ability to waive certain inadmissibility grounds for eligible family members, thus potentially alleviating fears for many families facing deportation risks.

The introduction of this bill reflects a broader shift in discussions around immigration policy, emphasizing compassion and the importance of family. With numerous co-sponsors from both parties, the act seeks to build bipartisan support in the fractured landscape of immigration reform. As the bill progresses through Congress, advocates for family unity hope it will lead to meaningful change for millions of families navigating the complexities of the U.S. immigration system.

headline: Rep. Houchin Introduces College Employment Accountability Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Erin Houchin, R-IN, has introduced the College Employment Accountability Act, aiming to reform how universities hire staff concerning undocumented immigrants. The bill seeks to prohibit institutions found employing unauthorized aliens from receiving federal student aid or institutional funding.

The motivation behind this legislation hinges on ongoing concerns about illegal immigration and its impact on federal resources. By mandating educational institutions to verify employment eligibility through the E-Verify program, the bill intends to ensure compliance with immigration laws and protect taxpayer-funded aid from being allocated to institutions that do not uphold these standards. 

If enacted, the law would impose strict penalties on universities not adhering to these hiring regulations, essentially barring them from accessing vital federal funds. This legislative move emphasizes accountability and aims at safeguarding taxpayer dollars, reflecting a growing trend among lawmakers to scrutinize immigration practices within educational institutions.

Contextually, this bill aligns with broader national conversations about border security and educational funding, suggesting legislative action motivated by both fiscal responsibility and immigration enforcement. Compliance with the E-Verify program is positioned as a critical element, showcasing an effort to tie employment practices directly to educational funding eligibility.

As the bill progresses, experts anticipate a heated debate regarding its potential implications on university operations and the broader educational framework. Stakeholders will likely voice concerns over the potential chilling effect on hiring practices and the implications for diversity within the academic workforce. Houchin's bill is currently under review by the House Committees on Education and Workforce and Judiciary, with deliberations expected to deepen as it moves forward in Congress.

headline: Rep. Ivey Introduces Raise the Age Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Glenn Ivey, D-MD, has introduced the Raise the Age Act, a legislative measure aimed at increasing the minimum age for purchasing certain firearms from 18 to 21 years. This proposed change targets semiautomatic centerfire rifles and shotguns, with exemptions for active military and full-time law enforcement personnel.

The Raise the Age Act comes in the wake of heightened concerns over gun violence and mass shootings in the United States. Advocates argue that raising the purchasing age could prevent firearms from falling into the hands of individuals who may not be mature enough to handle such powerful weapons responsibly. Research indicates that younger individuals are often involved in gun-related crimes, leading supporters to call for stricter regulations on firearms access.

The legislation proposes amendments to Title 18 of the United States Code, explicitly prohibiting federal firearms licensees from selling or delivering specific rifles and shotguns to anyone under 21. By instituting this age limit, the bill aims to foster a safer environment and reduce the rates of gun-related incidents among youth.

In addition to limiting access, the bill mandates a review of the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s operations concerning firearms licensing, ensuring that robust protocols are in place for background checks and information sharing. This oversight could enhance the screening process for firearm purchases, contributing to overall public safety.

The introduction of the Raise the Age Act reflects an ongoing national debate over gun control and the balance between individual rights and community safety. As the House Judiciary Committee reviews this proposal, it will likely spark further discussions on effective solutions to curb gun violence and protect future generations.

The bill (H.R. 2368) introduced on 03/26/2025 has 119 co-sponsors.

headline: Rep. Kelly Introduces PHIT Act of 2025
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mike Kelly, R-PA, has introduced the Personal Health Investment Today (PHIT) Act of 2025, aiming to amend the Internal Revenue Code to allow certain fitness-related expenses to be considered as medical expenses. This initiative intends to encourage healthier lifestyles and provide financial relief for individuals seeking to engage in physical activities.

The PHIT Act seeks to tackle obesity and related health issues by expanding the definition of qualified medical expenses. Under the proposed legislation, payments for gym memberships, fitness instruction, and certain exercise equipment can be deducted from taxable income, thereby incentivizing Americans to prioritize their health. This legislative effort underscores the growing recognition of the importance of preventive health care measures.

Rep. Kelly’s proposal comes amidst escalating concerns over rising obesity rates and chronic diseases linked to sedentary lifestyles. By allowing individuals to claim fitness expenses as medical deductions, the bill could alleviate the financial burden many face when pursuing healthier habits. The legislation is designed not just for personal fitness enthusiasts but also aims to benefit families, particularly those with limited resources for wellness activities.

The need for such legislation has gained momentum in recent years as policymakers increasingly focus on preventive health strategies. With healthcare costs continuously rising, encouraging fitness could lead to reduced long-term medical expenses for families and the healthcare system overall.

The PHIT Act of 2025 is currently under review by the House Committee on Ways and Means, and its passage could signify a pivotal shift in how Americans approach health and wellness investments. As the conversation around healthcare continues to evolve, this bill represents a proactive strategy to promote comprehensive wellness among citizens.

headline: Rep. Kim Introduces Taiwan Travel and Tourism Coordination Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Young Kim, R-CA, introduced the Taiwan Travel and Tourism Coordination Act to enhance cooperation between the United States and Taiwan in the areas of travel and tourism. This legislation aims to foster closer ties by improving the coordination of tourism-related activities, thus benefiting the economies of both regions.

The bill is designed to create a framework for collaboration between multiple U.S. governmental agencies, including the Departments of Commerce and State. It mandates that the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Travel and Tourism engage with Taiwanese authorities to expand tourism efforts. The proposed cooperation includes initiatives such as facilitating industry partnerships, promoting cultural heritage tourism, and ensuring the safety of international visitors.

Amid heightened geopolitical tensions in the Indo-Pacific region, the bill reflects U.S. priorities in bolstering economic ties with Taiwan. By addressing tourism, a critical aspect of U.S.-Taiwan relations, the act seeks to strengthen mutual economic interests. Enhanced travel between the two nations is anticipated to generate significant economic activity, boosting local businesses involved in hospitality, transportation, and retail sectors.

Moreover, the act outlines a reporting requirement to Congress, ensuring transparency in the implementation of cooperation efforts. These reports will detail the progress and challenges faced, helping to maintain accountability in U.S. engagements with Taiwan.

The introduction of the Taiwan Travel and Tourism Coordination Act signals a strategic initiative to deepen bilateral relations at a crucial time. As Congress considers this legislation, it highlights the importance of tourism as not just an economic driver but also a tool for diplomatic engagement and cultural exchange between the United States and Taiwan.

headline: Rep. Liccardo Introduces Scarper Ridge Golden Gate National Recreation Area Boundary Adjustment Act
body_txt:

Sam Liccardo, D-CA, has introduced the Scarper Ridge Golden Gate National Recreation Area Boundary Adjustment Act aimed at incorporating the Scarper Ridge property into the existing boundaries of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area. By protecting Scarper Ridge, the bill seeks to safeguard the area from development pressures, ensuring its ecological integrity for future generations.

The potential impact of this bill extends beyond conservation; it is expected to foster tourism and recreational activities in the region. The incorporation of Scarper Ridge is projected to attract visitors interested in hiking, birdwatching, and enjoying the natural beauty of California's coastal landscapes. This expansion stands to benefit local businesses catering to outdoor enthusiasts, further bolstering the economy.

The bill not only addresses immediate conservation concerns but also reflects broader environmental priorities shared by many California constituents advocating for sustainable land use.

headline: Rep. Friedman Introduces Don’t Penalize Victims Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Laura Friedman, D-CA, has introduced the Don’t Penalize Victims Act, aiming to amend the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The legislation seeks to address issues related to the duplication of benefits, ensuring that disaster victims receive the full relief they are entitled to without penalization.

The bill was introduced against the backdrop of widespread concern over federal disaster recovery policies, which have often faced criticism for being overly complex and punitive to those affected by natural disasters. Many disaster survivors have reported challenges in securing the benefits they need, particularly when overlapping assistance from different sources puts them at risk of losing vital financial support.

By revising the regulations that govern benefit duplication, the Don’t Penalize Victims Act intends to streamline the recovery process and provide clearer pathways for victims to access necessary funding. This change could potentially ease the burdens faced by individuals and families struggling to rebuild their lives after disasters, allowing them to navigate the assistance process more effectively.

If enacted, this bill would not only enhance the assistance available to disaster survivors but also serve as a legislative recognition of the complexities involved in disaster response. The act could facilitate quicker and more equitable financial recovery for those impacted by catastrophes such as hurricanes, wildfires, and floods.

The introduction of this bill underscores a growing recognition among lawmakers of the urgent need to reform disaster relief protocols. As discussions on disaster management continue, advocacy groups have expressed support for measures that prioritize the needs of victims and simplify the relief process to prevent financial hardship. Rep. Friedman and her co-sponsors, representing various constituencies, aim to ensure that those in dire need are no longer penalized during their moment of recovery.

headline: Rep. Fry Introduces Federal Law Enforcement Officer Service Weapon Purchase Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Russell Fry, R-SC, has introduced the Federal Law Enforcement Officer Service Weapon Purchase Act, aimed at allowing federal law enforcement officers to purchase their retired service weapons. The proposed bill seeks to establish a formal program under which these officers can buy back firearms from their agencies within six months of retirement.

This legislation comes in response to ongoing discussions regarding the disposal of surplus firearms and the sentiment among many law enforcement personnel favoring the ability to retain their service weapons. Supporters argue that allowing officers to purchase their retired weapons benefits both the officers and the agencies. It provides a sense of continuity and personal connection to the firearms they used during their service, while also simplifying the process of managing retired weapons for federal agencies.

If passed, the bill would require the General Services Administration to implement a program allowing officers to buy their firearms at salvage value, encouraging responsible ownership and use of retired weapons. This provision could help mitigate the potential for retired firearms to end up in the wrong hands, as current disposal methods may not always ensure secure handling.

The bill addresses not only the needs of federal law enforcement officers but also serves as a proactive approach to weapon management within federal agencies. By establishing parameters and clear guidelines, the act aims to ensure that these transactions uphold public safety while honoring the service of law enforcement professionals.

As the legislation moves forward, it will undergo scrutiny in the House Judiciary Committee, which is set to evaluate its implications and consider amendments. This process will help gauge the level of congressional support for the bill, while also assessing its potential impact on law enforcement practices across the nation.

The bill (H.R. 2255) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Garamendi Introduces National Rosie the Riveter Day Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. John Garamendi, D-CA, has introduced the National Rosie the Riveter Day Act, aiming to designate March 21 as a day to honor the contributions of women workers during World War II. This initiative seeks to recognize over six million women who joined the workforce during the war, often taking on challenging and crucial roles in support of the nation's effort.

The bill was introduced to preserve the legacy of the Rosie the Riveters, who left their homes to work in factories, shipyards, and other industries while facing significant societal challenges including discrimination and prejudice. By establishing a designated day of remembrance, the legislation hopes to promote awareness of their struggles and successes, inspiring future generations. The legislation also requests that the President issue an annual proclamation to commemorate this day, calling upon communities to engage in activities that reflect on the vital roles these women played in shaping history.

Designating March 21 as National Rosie the Riveter Day aligns with Women's History Month, serving as an appropriate tribute to working women across the United States. This effort seeks to foster cooperation and recognition among past, present, and future contributors to the workforce. The recognition is particularly poignant considering the recent historical movement towards celebrating women's rights and achievements.

The bill is currently referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform for further consideration. Should it pass, it would serve as a formal acknowledgment of the significant yet often overlooked impact women had on the home front during World War II, reasserting the importance of women's contributions to American society and the workforce.

The bill (H.R. 2256) introduced on 03/21/2025 has 5 co-sponsors: Rep. Huffman, Jared [D-CA-2]...03/21/2025; Rep. Mullin, Kevin [D-CA-15]...03/21/2025; Rep. Fitzpatrick, Brian K. [R-PA-1]...03/21/2025; Rep. Dingell, Debbie [D-MI-6]...03/21/2025; Rep. DeSaulnier, Mark [D-CA-10]...03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Garbarino Introduces National Fallen Firefighters Memorial Coin Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Andrew Garbarino, R-NY, has introduced the National Fallen Firefighters Memorial Coin Act, which aims to honor the service and sacrifice of firefighters across the United States. The legislation proposes the minting and issuance of commemorative coins to celebrate the National Fallen Firefighters Memorial, an initiative that is both a tribute and a means of supporting the National Fallen Firefighters Foundation.

The introduction of this bill stems from a desire to recognize the vital role firefighters play in protecting communities and the ultimate sacrifices they often make. The proposed coins would serve not only as a symbol of gratitude but also as a tangible asset to support firefighter-related programs and initiatives through proceeds from their sales. The Act specifies that the Secretary of the Treasury will mint three iterations of the coin: a $5 gold coin, a $1 silver coin, and a half-dollar clad coin, with a portion of the sales price designated as a surcharge benefiting the Foundation.

This initiative marks an important recognition of firefighters’ contributions and the challenges they face daily. With an estimated 1.1 million firefighters in the U.S., this acknowledgment extends to the extensive sacrifices made by them and their families. The coins will feature designs emblematic of the Memorial and will include inscriptions reflective of American values such as Liberty and In God We Trust.

By establishing this commemorative coin series, the National Fallen Firefighters Memorial Coin Act seeks to create an ongoing legacy of remembrance while also providing financial support to programs dedicated to the well-being of the firefighting community. The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Financial Services for further consideration.

The bill (H.R. 2257) introduced on 03/21/2025 has 6 co-sponsors: Rep. Pettersen, Brittany [D-CO-7]...03/21/2025; Rep. Fitzpatrick, Brian K. [R-PA-1]...03/21/2025; Rep. headline: Rep. Golden Introduces National Museum of Forestry and Logging History Bill
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Jared Golden, D-ME, has introduced legislation to designate the Maine Forest and Logging Museum, located in Bradley, Maine, as the National Museum of Forestry and Logging History. This bill aims to recognize the museum's historical and cultural significance related to forestry and logging in the United States.

The proposal is a crucial move to elevate the museum's visibility and status on a national level. By designating it as the National Museum of Forestry and Logging History, Golden aims to enhance public awareness and tourism, potentially boosting the local economy. The Maine Forest and Logging Museum has operated since 1990, showcasing the state's rich logging traditions, educational exhibits, and artifacts that reflect the industry's vital role in Maine's history and economy.

This initiative emerged from a growing recognition of the importance of preserving and promoting forestry heritage, particularly as the industry faces modern challenges related to sustainability and environmental stewardship. Proponents argue that recognizing the museum at a national level will highlight the historical impact of logging on American landscapes and communities, providing a platform for education about responsible forestry practices.

The bill emphasizes not only preservation but also the need for educational outreach. It is poised to attract further partnerships and funding opportunities for the museum, which could enhance its programs and exhibits. As the bill progresses through the legislative process, stakeholders from the forestry industry, environmental groups, and local communities are rallying support, believing that this designation will foster appreciation for Maine's natural resources and the traditions rooted in them.

The legislation has been referred to the House Committee on Agriculture for review, reflecting the bill's connection to agriculture and rural development themes in federal policy.

The bill (H.R. 2258) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Gonzales Introduces National Strategy for School Security Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Tony Gonzales, R-TX, has introduced the National Strategy for School Security Act, aiming to develop a comprehensive federal strategy to secure elementary and secondary schools against terrorism. The bill, which was introduced on March 21, 2025, seeks to amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002, requiring the Department of Homeland Security to collaborate with the Department of Education and other agencies to create a structured response to potential threats.

The introduction of this legislation comes in response to the increasing concerns about school safety, particularly amid a backdrop of rising security threats. The proposed strategy would mandate the federal government to systematically review and address vulnerabilities in school systems while ensuring preparedness for potential terrorist activities. By establishing a concerted plan, the legislation seeks to enhance safety protocols and provide necessary resources for schools across the nation.

If enacted, the bill would require the Secretary of Homeland Security to submit a national school security strategy within a year. This strategy would include an assessment of current federal programs, identification of specific vulnerabilities, and detailed actions necessary to close security gaps. It is designed to be dynamic, allowing for annual updates to adapt to evolving threats and fortify school defenses effectively.

A key component of the bill is its focus on collaboration across federal agencies, ensuring that schools are not working in isolation. The collaborative framework aims to utilize insights from various evaluations to provide a comprehensive approach, preventing unnecessary duplications of efforts.

As public scrutiny over school safety escalates, the National Strategy for School Security Act seeks to assure parents and communities that measures are being taken to protect students in educational settings.

headline: Rep. Griffith Introduces Richard H. Poff Post Office Building Bill
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. H. Morgan Griffith, R-VA, has introduced a bill aimed at designating the United States Postal Service facility located at 901 West Main Street in Radford, Virginia, as the Richard H. Poff Post Office Building. The bill seeks to honor Richard H. Poff, a prominent figure in Virginia's political history, and acknowledge his contributions to public service.

This bill was introduced in response to calls from local constituents and civic leaders who believe that naming the post office after Poff would not only recognize his legacy but also foster community pride. Richard H. Poff served as a member of the U.S. House of Representatives from 1953 to 1973, during which he made significant contributions in various capacities, including his role in the House Judiciary Committee.

If passed, the bill would not only rename the post office but also provide a lasting tribute to Poff's commitment to public service. Designating public buildings after notable individuals helps to preserve their legacies and serves to inspire future generations. Residents of Radford have expressed strong support for the initiative, viewing it as a way to connect the city’s present with its historical roots.

The introduction of H.R.2260 underscores the importance of recognizing local history and figures who contributed to the nation. The bill has been referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform for further consideration. The potential passage of this bill is planned for the coming months, reflecting a continued effort to honor individuals who have shaped their communities and the nation at large.

The bill (H.R. 2260) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Hernández Introduces Strengthening Oversight of DHS Intelligence Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Pablo Hernández, D-PR, has introduced the Strengthening Oversight of DHS Intelligence Act, a legislative initiative aimed at enhancing the Department of Homeland Security’s (DHS) oversight of intelligence operations. The bill seeks to amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002, ensuring that the sharing, retention, and dissemination of intelligence information align with the protection of privacy rights, civil rights, and civil liberties.

The introduction of this bill comes in the wake of increasing public concern over privacy and civil liberties in the context of national security. As intelligence operations have expanded, critics argue that oversight mechanisms have not kept pace, potentially leading to violations of individual rights. The proposed legislation intends to establish clearer guidelines requiring coordination with the Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis to safeguard these rights. 

Key provisions include mandates for training intelligence personnel about privacy rights and civil liberties, which reflects a growing awareness of the importance of ethical practices in intelligence work. The framework aims to create a balance between effective national security measures and the protection of citizens' rights.

The potential impact of the Strengthening Oversight of DHS Intelligence Act is significant; if enacted, it would formalize oversight practices that could lead to more transparent intelligence activities. By reinforcing accountability within the DHS, the act seeks to foster greater public trust in government operations.

As this bill moves to the Committee on Homeland Security, supporters hope it will be viewed favorably, citing the need for an increase in safeguards crucial to maintaining the balance between security and individual liberties. The bill's future remains contingent on committee discussions and potential amendments before any considerations in the full House.

The bill (H.R. 2261) introduced on 03/21/2025 has 1 co-sponsor: Rep. Thompson, Bennie G. [D-MS-2]...04/01/2025.

headline: Rep. Hinson Introduces Flexibility for Workers Education Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Ashley Hinson, R-IA, has introduced the Flexibility for Workers Education Act, seeking to amend the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. The bill aims to exclude certain non-productive times from the calculation of hours worked, specifically regarding employee participation in lectures and training programs outside regular working hours.

The introduction of this bill comes amid ongoing discussions about improving workplace flexibility and addressing employee concerns over unpaid hours spent on professional development. Many workers report having to attend mandatory training and other non-work-related activities without compensation, leading to increased frustration and calls for reform. Proponents argue that this bill would provide essential flexibility for workers, allowing them to choose professional development opportunities without the pressure of financial penalties for non-attendance.

If enacted, the legislation would clarify that time spent changing clothes or participating in employer-sponsored training would not count as hours worked, provided these activities are voluntary and occur outside of regular hours. This means employees would be incentivized to engage in additional training opportunities without risking overtime violations, potentially enhancing their skills and career prospects without impacting their take-home pay.

The potential impact of this bill is significant, particularly in industries that rely heavily on continuous education and training. As organizations evolve and adopt new technologies, employee skills must keep pace. However, the challenge remains in ensuring that voluntary participation leads to genuine skill development without inadvertently creating a divide between those who can afford to invest time and those who cannot.

The Flexibility for Workers Education Act will now be reviewed by the House Committee on Education and Workforce, where its future will be determined as lawmakers assess its implications on labor practices nationwide.

The bill (H.R. 2262) introduced on 03/21/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. Letlow, Julia [R-LA-5]...03/21/2025; Rep. Messmer, Mark [R-IN-8]...03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Khanna Introduces Telehealth Coverage Act of 2025
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Ro Khanna, D-CA, has introduced the Telehealth Coverage Act of 2025, a significant piece of legislation aimed at permanently extending and expanding telehealth services covered under Medicare. This action comes in response to the growing demand for remote healthcare services, particularly highlighted during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The bill seeks to amend the Social Security Act to maintain the telehealth flexibilities that were temporarily authorized during the pandemic. It aims to expand access to these services by removing in-person requirements for certain procedures, making it easier for patients to receive care from their homes. This legislative effort could have a profound impact on millions of Americans, especially those living in rural or underserved areas where healthcare access is limited.

The initiative reflects a broader shift towards embracing digital health solutions. By ensuring that telehealth can remain a viable option, the Act intends to address ongoing healthcare challenges, including accessibility and affordability. The proposed measures will allow a broader range of healthcare practitioners to provide telehealth services and include provisions for utilizing audio-only communications, expanding the definition of eligible telehealth services.

As telehealth has become increasingly integral to the healthcare landscape, this bill represents an essential move to establish a more permanent infrastructure for virtual care. By addressing the needs of diverse patient populations—especially those with limited English proficiency or those requiring specific medical follow-ups—the Act emphasizes inclusivity and comprehensive care.

The Telehealth Coverage Act of 2025 has been referred to the House Committees on Energy and Commerce and Ways and Means for further consideration. Khanna’s efforts underscore a commitment to modernizing healthcare delivery, aligning with ongoing initiatives to enhance patient care through technology.

The bill (H.R. 2263) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Lawler Introduces Service-Connected Suicide Compensation Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Michael Lawler, R-NY, has introduced the Service-Connected Suicide Compensation Act, aiming to provide financial support for the families of veterans suffering from service-connected mental disorders who tragically die by suicide. The bill would mandate the automatic payment of dependency and indemnity compensation to the survivors of affected veterans, ensuring they receive necessary assistance during a profoundly difficult time.

The introduction of this bill comes amid growing concerns regarding the mental health crisis facing veterans, particularly those battling service-related mental illnesses. Estimates suggest that many veterans may face heightened risks of suicide due to these conditions, making legislation that aids their families a critical step in addressing this pressing issue.

If enacted, the Service-Connected Suicide Compensation Act would amend Title 38 of the United States Code, directing the Department of Veterans Affairs to prioritize the needs of survivors in the aftermath of a veteran's suicide related to a diagnosed mental disorder. This legislative effort underscores the urgent need to address the ongoing mental health challenges within the veteran community and the devastating impact of suicide.

The proposed policy could have far-reaching implications. By providing financial support, it seeks to alleviate some of the burdens faced by grieving families, thereby contributing to their emotional and financial stability. Supporters believe that this act may encourage more open discussions about mental health within the military and help streamline assistance for those in dire circumstances.

This bill has been referred to the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs for further consideration. As lawmakers delve deeper into mental health issues, the passage of the Service-Connected Suicide Compensation Act may represent a critical step toward honoring and supporting America's veterans and their families.

The bill (H.R. 2264) introduced on 03/21/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. Conaway, Herbert [D-NJ-3]...03/21/2025; Rep. Wittman, Robert J. [R-VA-1]...03/25/2025.

headline: Rep. Malliotakis Introduces No Foreign Election Interference Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Nicole Malliotakis, R-NY, has introduced the No Foreign Election Interference Act aimed at curbing foreign influence in U.S. political campaigns. This legislation seeks to impose penalties on tax-exempt organizations that receive contributions from foreign nationals and subsequently donate to political committees.

The motivation behind this bill stems from increasing concerns over foreign interference in American elections, particularly in the wake of recent controversies surrounding campaign funding. Advocates for the bill argue that foreign contributions can undermine the integrity of the democratic process, prompting calls for stricter regulations. Under this proposed legislation, organizations that accept foreign contributions and make political donations would face severe financial penalties, amounting to double the contribution made. Furthermore, repeat offenders could risk losing their tax-exempt status entirely, should they violate the new rules more than twice.

The potential impact of the No Foreign Election Interference Act is significant, as it aims to create a more transparent and accountable political financing system. By deterring foreign contributions, the bill seeks to bolster voter confidence in the legitimacy of election outcomes. Legislative watchers note that this move could provoke debate among lawmakers over the balance between free speech in political funding and safeguarding national sovereignty in the electoral process.

The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means for further consideration. If passed, the amendments would take effect for contributions made after January 1, 2026. As political dynamics evolve, the No Foreign Election Interference Act represents a proactive step toward addressing the complexities of foreign influence in U.S. politics.

The bill (H.R. 2265) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Massie Introduces NICS Data Reporting Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Thomas Massie, R-KY, has introduced the NICS Data Reporting Act, a proposed legislation aimed at enhancing transparency regarding firearm purchase eligibility. The bill mandates that the Attorney General submits an annual report containing demographic data on individuals found ineligible to purchase firearms via the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS). 

Massie's initiative responds to ongoing debates about firearm regulations and the demographics of those affected by restrictions. Advocates argue that understanding the demographic makeup of those denied gun purchases is vital for assessing the fairness and effectiveness of the current gun control framework. The bill stipulates that the annual report must include details such as race, ethnicity, national origin, sex, age, disability status, and average annual income of the rejected applicants.

The potential impact of this legislation can be profound, as it seeks to inform lawmakers and the public about who is disproportionately affected by firearm restrictions. Supporters claim that increased transparency will enable more informed discussions around policy reforms and possible improvements to the background check process. 

Previously, there has been criticism regarding the lack of comprehensive data in understanding how gun regulations impact various communities. By requiring the reporting of demographic information, the NICS Data Reporting Act aims to provide a clearer picture, possibly addressing concerns about bias in the implementation of gun laws.

The bill has been brought before the House Judiciary Committee, marking its first step towards legislative consideration. As potential discussions unfold, stakeholders from various political backgrounds are likely to weigh in on the significance of demographic data in shaping future gun policy.

The bill (H.R. 2267) introduced on 03/21/2025 has 2 co-sponsors: Rep. Cline, Ben [R-VA-6]...03/21/2025; Rep. Spartz, Victoria [R-IN-5]...03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. McClain Introduces WIPPES Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Lisa McClain, R-MI, has introduced the Wastewater Infrastructure Pollution Prevention and Environmental Safety Act, known as the WIPPES Act, aimed at curbing environmental hazards associated with disposable wipes. The proposed legislation mandates “Do Not Flush” labeling on certain products, particularly premoistened wipes, which are often incorrectly flushed and contribute significantly to wastewater management challenges.

This legislation is a response to the growing concern over the environmental impact of improperly flushed disposable wipes that can clog sewage systems and lead to costly infrastructure damage. With communities facing increased expenses from maintaining and repairing their wastewater treatment systems, the WIPPES Act seeks to mitigate these issues through preventative labeling standards.

Under this bill, manufacturers would be required to clearly label their products with a recognizable symbol and the text “Do Not Flush,” ensuring consumers are aware of proper disposal methods. This labeling would apply to wipes marketed for personal care, cleaning, and household use, helping to educate the public about the potential risks associated with flushing such materials.

The WIPPES Act is anticipated to have a dual impact: reducing the environmental burden on wastewater systems and informing consumers about the appropriate disposal methods for these products. As the market for disposable wipes continues to expand, this legislation emphasizes the necessity for responsible consumer behavior and increased manufacturer accountability.

McClain's bill has garnered support from other lawmakers, including Mr. Mullin, Mr. Kean, and Mr. Huffman, and was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce for further consideration. If enacted, the law would bolster efforts to safeguard water systems while promoting more sustainable practices among consumers and manufacturers alike.

The bill (H.R. 2269) introduced on 03/21/2025 has 4 co-sponsors: Rep. Mullin, Kevin [D-CA-15]...03/21/2025; Rep. Kean, Thomas H. [R-NJ-7]...03/21/2025; Rep. Huffman, Jared [D-CA-2]...03/21/2025; Rep. Pingree, Chellie [D-ME-1]...04/09/2025.

headline: Rep. Messmer Introduces Empowering Employer Child and Elder Care Solutions Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mark Messmer, R-IN, has introduced the Empowering Employer Child and Elder Care Solutions Act, a legislative proposal aimed at facilitating employer-supported childcare and dependent care services. The bill seeks to amend the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 by excluding payments and services for childcare from overtime compensation calculations.

The introduction of this bill is a response to the growing concerns about workforce retention and productivity. Many employers struggle to retain staff due to the increasing demands of childcare and elder care responsibilities that employees face. Messmer's solution aims to alleviate this burden by allowing employers to provide childcare support without the financial implications of affecting overtime pay.

Should the bill pass, it is expected to have a significant impact on both employers and workers. By facilitating access to childcare and elder care services, the legislation could help reduce absenteeism and increase job satisfaction among employees who juggle caregiving and work. Ultimately, supporters argue that this act will enhance workforce participation by making it easier for parents and caregivers to balance home and job commitments.

Historically, the lack of adequate support for childcare has been a persistent challenge in the American labor market. As more families rely on dual incomes, the need for viable care solutions has become increasingly critical. The proposed changes seek to empower employers by making it more feasible for them to offer supplementary care services without incurring additional financial penalties.

The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Education and Workforce and has already garnered attention from various stakeholders concerned about labor and family welfare. The legislative process will determine the viability of this proposal, with discussions around its implications likely to shape future employment policies.

headline: Rep. Owens Introduces Change of Ownership and Conversion Improvement Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Burgess Owens, R-UT, has introduced the Change of Ownership and Conversion Improvement Act aimed at streamlining the review process for changes of control among higher education institutions. The bill was presented to the House on March 21, 2025, and will modify the application procedure under the Higher Education Act of 1965.

The legislation responds to challenges faced by educational institutions during mergers and acquisitions, which often delay necessary transformations within the sector. Current review processes by the Department of Education are criticized for taking excessive time, sometimes up to five years. By expediting these reviews, the act intends to encourage beneficial mergers that promote innovation and student-centered improvements across American education.

Moreover, the bill empowers the Department of Education to charge a fee for processing change-of-ownership applications, ensuring that the entities involved bear the financial burden rather than taxpayers. Fees collected will directly support enhancing the review capacity of the Department. By mandating expedited evaluations, the act strives to reduce unnecessary bureaucratic delays, promoting timely operational changes within institutions that can enhance overall educational effectiveness.

Owens emphasized that with changing demographics and evolving educational demands, more institutions are likely to consider mergers or conversions in the coming years. The process outlined in the act includes provisions for robust monitoring of newly converted nonprofit institutions to prevent financial mismanagement or ethical conflicts. This proactive approach ensures that higher education remains responsive to the evolving needs of students and society at large.

As universities and colleges navigate a rapidly changing environment, the Change of Ownership and Conversion Improvement Act aims to modernize regulatory frameworks, making them more efficient and effective in meeting contemporary educational demands.

The bill (H.R. 2271) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

* * # * * 

Primary source of information: https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-bill/2271/text

headline: Rep. Pfluger Introduces FAFSA Act of 2025
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. August Pfluger, R-TX, has introduced the Freeze Aid For Student Assaulters Act of 2025, aiming to restrict certain individuals from receiving federal financial aid under Title IV of the Higher Education Act. The bill proposes that those convicted of specific offenses—including assault against police officers or rioting—should be deemed ineligible for federal educational support.

The introduction of this legislation follows rising concerns over campus violence and the safety of educational environments. By targeting individuals with serious criminal backgrounds, the bill seeks to foster a safer atmosphere in higher education institutions. Advocates argue that disallowing these individuals from accessing federal aid is a necessary step to hold them accountable and to discourage violent behavior in academic settings.

If enacted, the FAFSA Act of 2025 would apply to any individual convicted of violent crimes defined under the bill's provisions. Those affected would not only lose eligibility for grants and loans but would also be required to repay any federal grants received previously, which would then convert to loans with interest. This stringent policy intends to emphasize the seriousness of these offenses and their consequences regarding higher education support.

Supporters of the bill believe that it serves as a deterrent against violent conduct, contributing positively to campus safety and integrity. Critics, however, raise concerns about the potential consequences for students who may make mistakes but are otherwise on a rehabilitative path. As the bill moves to the House Committee on Education and Workforce, it will be a pivotal moment for both supporters and opponents to voice their views on this contentious issue surrounding education and public safety.

headline: Rep. Pfluger Introduces UPRISERS Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. August Pfluger, R-TX, introduced the UPRISERS Act on March 21, 2025, aiming to enhance immigration enforcement regarding foreign students. The bill proposes to revoke the visas of international students who have been convicted of assaulting a police officer or related offenses, such as rioting.

The introduction of the UPRISERS Act comes amidst ongoing national debates about crime, public safety, and college campuses' political climates. The bill underscores concerns surrounding the behavior of a minority of foreign students, particularly those participating in protests that escalate into violence. By targeting specific offenses linked to law enforcement and public order, the legislation seeks to tighten controls over student visa eligibility and maintain a safe environment in the country.

If enacted, the UPRISERS Act would allow the Secretary of State to revoke student visas for individuals admitted under sections 101(a)(15)(F), (J), or (M) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, targeting those convicted of assaults on law enforcement or rioting-related offenses. Furthermore, it would classify such violations as grounds for deportation, thus amplifying the stakes for international students regarding their conduct while in the United States.

Supporters of the bill argue it is a necessary measure to protect communities from violence associated with protests. Critics, however, warn that it could unjustly affect students engaging in peaceful activism or dissent, raising fears of infringement on rights and freedoms. As the conversation around immigration and crime continues, Rep. Pfluger's UPRISERS Act has entered the legislative arena, with implications for future policies regarding foreign students in the U.S. The bill is currently under review by the House Committee on the Judiciary.

The bill (H.R. 2273) was introduced on [Introduction Date].

headline: Rep. Rose Introduces Court Shopping Deterrence Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. John W. Rose, R-TN, has introduced the Court Shopping Deterrence Act, a significant piece of legislation aimed at addressing the issue of nationwide injunctions issued by district courts. This bill proposes a framework where appeals of these injunctions will be directed exclusively to the Supreme Court, aiming to streamline judicial processes and reduce the forums available for legal challenges.

The introduction of this bill comes on the heels of growing concerns about the broad and often disparate impacts of nationwide injunctions. Critics argue that such injunctions create inconsistent legal standards across the country, allowing certain parties to shop for judges who are more likely to rule in their favor. By mandating that appeals of nationwide injunctions go directly to the Supreme Court, the bill seeks to establish a unified legal precedent, ensuring a consistent interpretation of federal laws.

If enacted, the Court Shopping Deterrence Act could reshape how cases related to federal statutes and regulations are handled in lower courts, potentially expediting legal proceedings. This decisiveness may also help uphold the integrity of federal authority, reducing instances where divergent rulings impede implementation of national policies.

Additionally, the bill aims to address concerns raised by lawmakers and legal experts regarding the expanding power of district judges, which can create an imbalance in the judicial system. By focusing appeal jurisdictions, the legislation intends to safeguard against overreach and clarify the Supreme Court's role as the final arbiter in matters of significant national concern.

The bill has been referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary for further consideration, where it will undergo scrutiny and evaluation before potentially moving to the floor for a vote.

The bill (H.R. 2274) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Roy Introduces SCHOOL Act of 2025
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Chip Roy, R-TX, has introduced the SCHOOL Act of 2025, a legislative proposal aimed at allowing federal education funds to follow students regardless of their chosen educational environment—be it public, private, or home schooling. This bill seeks to modernize funding approaches under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, promoting greater educational choice for families across Texas and the nation.

The introduction of the SCHOOL Act comes amid growing calls for educational reform, particularly in light of the disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Many parents had to navigate shifting learning formats and are now advocating for increased flexibility in how educational funds are allocated. By allowing funds to be tied directly to students, supporters of the bill argue it will empower families to choose the institutions that best suit their children's needs and learning styles.

If passed, the SCHOOL Act would enable state educational agencies to allocate federal grant funds in a manner that considers each child's enrollment in their respective educational settings. This includes provisions for using these funds for a variety of educational resources, from curriculum materials to private school tuition, thereby broadening the scope of how families can support their children's education.

Critics of the bill, however, warn of potential downsides, including concerns about the redirection of funds from public schools and the risk of exacerbating educational inequalities. With the bill now referred to the House Committee on Education and Workforce, it will undergo further scrutiny before any potential advancement in Congress. The impact of this legislation could be significant, establishing a framework for educational funding that reflects the diverse learning preferences of students across the country.

The bill (H.R. 2275) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

* * # * *

headline: Rep. Roy Introduces CRT Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Chip Roy, R-TX, has introduced the Combating Racist Teaching in Schools Act, aimed at prohibiting federal funding to educational institutions that promote certain race-based theories. The bill, which seeks to address what its proponents view as problematic educational practices, focuses on preventing the allocation of federal funds to schools that encourage teachings suggesting the superiority or inferiority of races or perceive the U.S. as fundamentally racist.

The introduction of the CRT Act comes amidst an ongoing national debate regarding the teaching of Critical Race Theory (CRT) and related topics in educational institutions across the country. Advocates argue that some race-based theories can contribute to divisive narratives and undermine national unity, while opponents contend that they are essential for understanding systemic racism and its impact on society.

If passed, the legislation would prevent federal aid from reaching any educational institution that teaches or requires belief in concepts that classify individuals by race in a negative or prejudicial light. This could significantly affect funding for schools that incorporate comprehensive curricula including discussions of race, identity, and history, leading to potential challenges for state and local education agencies seeking federal support. 

The bill is part of a broader effort among some legislators to address perceived ideological biases in educational settings. Proponents argue it aims to cleanse educational content of radical racial theories, while critics warn it might restrict discussions on race, privilege, and historical injustices. As it moves to the House Committee on Education and Workforce, the outcome may reshape how educational institutions address race-related topics and how they receive federal funding.

The bill (H.R. 2276) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Sessions Introduces FACT Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Pete Sessions, R-TX, has introduced the Federal Accountability Committee for Transparency Act (FACT Act), aiming to enhance oversight and accountability of federal pandemic spending. The bill seeks to extend the life of the Pandemic Response Accountability Committee (PRAC) until December 2026 while simultaneously renaming it to the Fraud Prevention and Accountability Committee.

The FACT Act responds to growing concerns about the substantial funds disbursed during the COVID-19 pandemic, which have reportedly been susceptible to fraud. By transforming PRAC into the Fraud Prevention and Accountability Committee, the proposed legislation emphasizes the responsibility to scrutinize the government’s use of pandemic-related funds meticulously. With the extension of oversight, lawmakers believe this alteration will ensure that measures are put in place to prevent waste and fraud before it occurs.

The extension and rebranding of this committee come at a time when public confidence in regulatory bodies is crucial. Recent audits revealed alarming instances of misuse of funds intended for pandemic relief, underscoring the need for stronger oversight mechanisms. Through the FACT Act, Rep. Sessions aims to address these vulnerabilities by maintaining a dedicated group focused solely on accountability in federal spending.

This legislation is significant as it seeks to pivot from mere compliance monitoring to a proactive approach in identifying and preventing fraud. The move to create a Fraud Prevention and Accountability Committee is expected to have a wide-ranging impact on federal financial management and could serve as a model for future accountability initiatives across various government programs. As it stands, the FACT Act will now move to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform for further evaluation.

The bill (H.R. 2277) introduced on 03/21/2025 has 4 co-sponsors: Rep. Comer, James [R-KY-1]...03/21/2025; Rep. Connolly, Gerald E. [D-VA-11]...03/21/2025; Rep. Mfume, Kweisi [D-MD-7]...03/24/2025; Rep. Subramanyam, Suhas [D-VA-10]...03/25/2025.

headline: Rep. Takano Introduces Survivor Benefits Delivery Improvement Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Mark Takano, D-CA, has introduced the Survivor Benefits Delivery Improvement Act, aimed at enhancing access to benefits for veterans’ survivors and improving outreach to those who have served in uniformed services. This legislation seeks to amend title 38 of the United States Code to ensure that dependents, including surviving spouses and children, have equitable access to essential benefits administered by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA).

The introduction of this bill is motivated by ongoing concerns regarding the inadequacy of current outreach efforts and accessibility for veterans' survivors, particularly from underserved demographics. The act intends to close gaps in support by mandating the collection of demographic data on recipients of various veterans’ benefits, which can help the VA better identify and reach out to those eligible for assistance.

One key aspect of the legislation is the requirement for the VA to develop an outreach strategy tailored for underserved demographics. This includes regular communication with survivors of veterans to ensure they are aware of available benefits, including disability compensation and burial benefits. Additionally, the bill calls for the establishment of full-time positions at VA call centers to assist in delivering these outreach services.

By providing data-driven insights into the demographics of benefit recipients, the Survivor Benefits Delivery Improvement Act aims to create a more inclusive framework that addresses the needs of all veterans' dependents, regardless of background or circumstances. This legislation poses the potential to significantly improve the quality of life for countless families affected by the loss of service members, enhancing their awareness of the support available during challenging times. The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs for further consideration.

The bill (H.R. 2278) was introduced on 03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Tenney Introduces No Tax on LOSAP Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Claudia Tenney, R-NY, has introduced the No Tax on LOSAP Act, aiming to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to increase the amount excluded from gross income for payments to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical services and clarify that payments under length of service award programs (LOSAP) are qualified payments.

The bill addresses the financial challenges faced by many volunteer first responders who often serve their communities without compensation. By raising the exclusion limit from $50 to $1,000, the legislation seeks to provide meaningful financial relief to those who dedicate countless hours to volunteer emergency services. Currently, funds awarded under LOSAP programs are often seen as taxable income, which can discourage participation and burden volunteers with unexpected tax liabilities.

The introduction of this bill comes at a crucial moment as many volunteer departments struggle to recruit and retain personnel. The legislation’s potential impact could help ease the financial burden on those involved in essential community services while fostering a more robust pipeline of volunteer responders. Furthermore, strengthening volunteer programs could enhance community preparedness for emergencies.

The bill is significant because it not only increases the financial benefits for first responders but also reinforces the value placed on their service. First responders play a critical role in community safety, and ensuring they are not penalized financially for their volunteer efforts is a priority for many legislators and constituents alike.

As the bill proceeds through the legislative process, its supporters hope it will garner bipartisan support, reflecting a widespread commitment to supporting volunteer service in emergency response across the nation. The No Tax on LOSAP Act was referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means for further consideration.

The bill (H.R. 2279) introduced on 03/21/2025 has 4 co-sponsors: Rep. Lawler, Michael [R-NY-17]...03/21/2025; Rep. Gillen, Laura [D-NY-4]...03/21/2025; Rep. Suozzi, Thomas R. [D-NY-3]...03/21/2025; Rep. Garbarino, Andrew R. [R-NY-2]...03/21/2025.

headline: Rep. Wasserman Schultz Introduces BIRD Energy and U.S.-Israel Energy Center Reauthorization Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, D-FL, has introduced the BIRD Energy and U.S.-Israel Energy Center Reauthorization Act, aimed at enhancing energy cooperation between the United States and Israel. This legislation seeks to extend and expand the existing United States-Israel Energy Cooperation program, which supports bilateral research and development in energy technologies.

The reauthorization of this program comes in light of the growing importance of energy innovation to both nations. The BIRD Energy Foundation was established in 2009 to foster collaboration in energy development, addressing challenges like clean energy commercialization and energy security. By increasing the funding cap from $2 million to $5 million and extending the program through fiscal year 2031, this bill seeks to bolster efforts in renewable energy, energy storage, and cybersecurity.

This legislative push reflects a commitment to tackle global energy issues with innovative solutions. Israel has been at the forefront of technological advancements in energy efficiency and renewables, making it an ideal partner for the U.S. in achieving shared energy goals. The bill expands the cooperation categories to include hydrogen energy, fusion energy, and even agrivoltaics, reflecting a broadening of the areas of focus to encompass new technologies critical to the future of energy.

The potential impact of this legislation is notable, with projections indicating that this enhanced partnership could create jobs, strengthen economic ties, and improve energy resilience. With rising global demand for sustainable energy solutions, the U.S.-Israel collaboration under this bill positions both nations to lead in energy innovation and security through strengthened ties and shared technological advancement.

headline: Rep. Wilson Introduces Strengthening Job Corps Act
body_txt:
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rep. Frederica S. Wilson, D-FL, has introduced the Strengthening Job Corps Act, aiming to reauthorize and enhance the Job Corps program to better assist opportunity youth in gaining essential skills for employment. This legislation outlines various modifications to the existing program, offering a comprehensive approach to meet the needs of young individuals seeking job training and education.

The Job Corps program has long served as a vital gateway for disadvantaged youth, providing them with educational resources and job training. However, many argue that the program requires updates to remain effective in today's workforce landscape. The reauthorization proposed in this bill seeks to expand access for participants by raising the maximum enrollment age to 28 for individuals with disabilities or justice-involved youth, thereby allowing more individuals to benefit from its services.

Among its noteworthy provisions, the bill includes enhanced performance metrics and accountability measures for Job Corps campuses, focusing on student outcomes such as employment rates and educational achievements post-graduation. This data-driven approach aims to ensure that participating campuses are held to higher standards, facilitating better preparation for the workforce for enrollees.

The legislation also addresses recruitment strategies, emphasizing the need for partnerships with local organizations and employers to create a more integrated support system for participants. By aligning the program more closely with local workforce development efforts, the bill aims to foster a pipeline of skilled workers tailored to meet community needs.

As Congress deliberates the Strengthening Job Corps Act, its potential impact on workforce development and youth empowerment continues to draw attention from various stakeholders, emphasizing the critical need for adaptive solutions in addressing today's employment challenges.

The bill (H.R. 2281) was introduced on 03/21/2025.
